div.p: THE GREAT SCANDERBERG: A NOVEL.
Done out of French.
LONDON, Printed for R. Bentley, at the Pot-Houe, in Ruel-Street in Covent-Garden, 1690.

div.head: To the Honoured Madam JEPHSON.
div.p: COuld the exactnes of this Performance but equal the greatnes of my Subject, or that Goodnes that put me upon it, I hould then have done that out of Choice, which I do now out of Obedience.
Nothing les than your Commands could have ingag'd me in the Attempt, and nothing les than your Character could have protected me in it.

Indeed my Hero is all Glory and Triumph, but yet he aures me this is his highet; and that he is more warmly affected with the Dedication, than with the Succes of his Adventures. But, Madam, what e're his Satisfactions may be, mine mut be allow'd to exceed them, on whom you have lain
o many Obligations, that I mut own them greater than all things, but the Generoity that conferr'd them, or the Humility that receiv'd them; and which to acknowledge, hall be as much the endeavours, as 'tis now the deires of,

closer.signed: Your mot Oblig'd, mot humble, and mot devoted Servant. N. V.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
IF Love is a Weaknes, one mut confes there is none that ought ooner to be excued, or that is Authoried by o many Examples. It would be a hard matter to find a Man of any Note, who has never been in Love: The greatet Heroes could not defend themelves againt its Power, and they valued their Crowns of Myrtle, no les than thoe of Laurel; the Pleaures which aroe to their Ambitious Minds from their many Exploits, and Illutrious Conquets, did not eem to them o weet, as thoe of Love. Alexander, and Cear, who had under their Command almot half the World, thought it Glorious for themelves to obey that Sex, which has always been the fairet part of it. Hercules himelf, that Prodigy of Strength and Valour, preferred the Fetters of a Woman, to the Honour of upholding Heaven, and the Gods themelves. One of Omphala's threatning looks could make this invincible Hero
tremble, his Armour was no Proof againt her Charms; her Ditaff eaily took place of his Club, and his Lyons Skin urrender'd to a Woman's Attire. Mars himelf the God of War, could not reit the Charms of the Goddes of Love, and he never thought himelf o happy, as when he har'd with Vulcan the Favours of Venus. Since then the greatet Heroes, and the Gods themelves, have been thus enamour'd; how can any wonder, that the Victorious Scanderberg, hould yield to the Charms of Ariania? This formidable Captain, who never fought without Victory, killed near two thouand Turks, with his own hand, without receiving the leat wound; but Love did what all his Enemies could not do, and wounded the Heart of this Invulnerable Conquerour. Ariania, tho' but a Slave, loaded with Chains that Vanquiher of the mot powerful Emperour in the World. But how paionate oever this King of Albania was, Love could never draw one word from him, or compel him to an Action, unworthy of himelf. The peron who inpires him with thee Dicoures, and thee Deigns, is ued to make Heroes both Speak and Act. And I am confident that the Amours of Scanderberg, will be as pleaant to the Ladies, as the great Tranactions of his Life have eem'd wonderful to thoe who have read them in his Hitory.

div.head: The Great Scanderberg. A NOVEL.
div.p:
VAlour and Virtue, appeared never with more Splendour, than in the Peron of the Invincible Scanderberg. This Prince was Bred up in the Seraglio of the Cruel Amurat, preerv'd there his Manners uncorrupt, and his Vertue may be propoed for an Example to all the Monarchs in the World. After he had freed himelf from a hameful Slavery, recovered his Father's Dominions, truck Terrour, by his Immortal Actions, into the heart of him who had Captivated his Youth, he
aw all his Lands Invaded by the Forces of the Ottoman Empire, which the angry Sultan led in Peron to the ight of the Walls of Croya, a Famous City, and the ordinary abode of the Kings of Albania.

p.U:
ince his return, had led there a Life which might have been called happy, if Love had not mixed its ad Dipleaures with the advantage of reigning over the hearts of all his Subjects; he had bore the dreadfullet brunts of War with unimaginable contancy; he had won Battels, conquered Provinces, vanquihed every where, and given Matter enough to Poterity for celebrating his Praies, there were till remaining ome formidable Enemies, powerful by their number, and dreadful for their fury, whoe only intent was to oppres him; but the fear of their Arms was not the thing, that diturbed his ret: Some more tender concerns, cat him into a orrowful Condition, and if care of his Subjects, by whom he was extreamly beloved, had not kept him at Croya, he had gone himelf to the Camp of the Enemy, to eek out the abent and unfortunate Ariania; all
the moments which he gave to other Affairs, eem'd to him as o many Crimes againt his Love; and Croya, which he could not leave with Honour, was a orrowful abode for him, by reaon of Ariania's Abence.

div.p: Notwithtanding the care of thoe, that feared for his Liberty, he did eek ometimes Solitary Places, to igh there with more Freedom, and would go a coniderable way from Croya. One Morning going out with ranus only, he teer'd his coure towards a Vally that eem'd more agreeable with his Melancholy.

The Turks had made already many Incurions, and gain'd ome mall Advantages, which the Sorrow of Scanderberg eem'd to neglect. ranus being olicitous for his Mater's danger, who was come o near his powerful Enemy, and having given him a coniderable while to think by himelf, topt him at lat, and hewing him Amurat's Tents, pake thus to him; Do you intend, My Lord, to go to the Sultan's Camp, and do you eriouly reflect upon that numerous Army, which bears uch an ill will to your Peron: That Life for which thou art o olicitous, anwer'd
the King of Albania, is not dear enough to me, to take any care of it; and my Eyes, deprived of the ight of Ariania, long to be deprived of that of the day: What, will you, My Lord, reply'd ranus, expoe to a dreadful Fate, a thing which is o dear to Ariania? I know what your Valour can do; but in our preent Condition—In our preent Condition, aid Scanderberg, do you think that the Army of Amurat can make me tremble? Was I but certain of eeing Ariania again, I would venture to fight it my elf alone: yes ure (added he, with one of thoe threatning looks, which had been often the Preages of his Victories) I would endeavour it. As he was going on, ome groaning that he heard from behind the Trees interrupted him. The Prince was Naturally bountiful, and thinking that might be ome oppreed Peron who wanted help, he run thither with hate, and found a Man wallowing in his Blood, this Man was a Turk, but Scanderberg whom no prejudice could hinder from being kind, drew nearer him, and knew preently (tho' in the Pangs of Death) Aradin, the firt of the Eunuchs of Amurat, who had taken care of him
in his Infancy, and by whom he was tenderly beloved; the unfortunate Aradin, tho' dying, knew alo the Features of the King of Albania, and, fetching a deep igh, he aid, Oh, Scanderberg! Amurat! Ariania! Knave and perfidious Muelman, I dye. And really he did o. This trange event was but a new increae of Grief for Scanderberg: The Nanies which Aradin had pronounced, pas'd to his very heart; he perceived the Eunuch had not poke, but after he had known him, and that he was nearly concerned in all thoe things, which Death had forced him to uppres: Jut Heavens, cry'd he, what News do you intend to tell me? Is Ariania Alive, or Dead? Ala¯s! Uranus, my dear Uranus, what perplexity do I find my elf now in? What can I do? What can I think? My Lord, reply'd ranus, if I may conjecture any thing, Ariania is not far from hence. Then he is in Amurat's Camp, reply'd the Amorous Prince of Albania, where he uffers the troubleome Solicitations of a Barbarous Emperour; or thoe of the unworthy Muulman. Suppoe it was o, am I the happier for it? Yes certainly, added he, for I would go and take
her away from the Ottomans.

Whilt Scanderberg was peaking, ranus went to look whether Aradin did breathe till, he found him cold, and without motion; but turning him, he perceived a Paper, like a Letter, jut over his Heart, and delivering it to his Mater, My Lord, aid he, this Note will tell you, may be, a part of that which the udden Death of Aradin hinder'd him from uttering; the Prince opened the Letter, and aw there a Sentence more cruel, than if it had been againt his own Life.

body.p: MY Love hath been prevailed upon at lat by my Wrath: Such a Man as I, ought not to hearken to pity; go then Orcan, and Sacrifice the ungrateful Ariania, to the Shame of having made me igh to no purpoe; her Blood will quench the ret of my Flame. Fear ome oppoition from Muelman, and whilt I hall vanquih the Rebellious Scanderberg, begin my Revenge that way, which will prove o orrowful to him. This is the Abolute Command of

div.p:
No Man could expres the ad effects the Reading of this Letter produced in the Soul of Scanderberg: In the firt fit of his Rage, he was ready to run towards the Ottoman Army; but ranus, after a long, but fruitles oppoition, laying aide his wonted repect, told him at lat: Do you eek an Inglorious Death, My Lord, and will not this Triumph of the Turks, blot out all the Splendour of your pat Life? Having lot Ariania, reply'd the Prince, I am reolv'd to dye in her Revenge. His Depair had likely prevailed over ranus's Zeal, if Thopia, a young Prince, and much addicted to Scanderberg, who was looking for him, becaue he knew he was gone out of Croya without his Train, had not come in the ame place. Thopia, aid the King of Albania to him, None is more worthy your pity than I: You, My Lord, anwered Thopia amazed, you! the Love, the Terrour, and the Admiration of the whole World, in your firt Youth, what Michiefs can cros o great Advantages? I perceive, reply'd Scanderberg, you judge of the Felicity of my Life, by thoe Actions which have made a great noie in the World; but do not decide it upon meer appearances. My Lord, added
Thopia, the Turks may urprize your Valour in this place: Let us go to Croya, where your Preence is wihed for. And o jointly with ranus, they obliged the Prince to go towards the City, but firt they took care of the Corps of Aradin, ome Albanian Troopers, who were riding about the City, to oberve the Motion of the Turks, carry'd it away by the King's Command.

Thopia knew very well that Scanderberg was in Love, but he was not acquainted with the Particulars of his Life, and hew'd a great Deire to know them. Scanderberg condecended eaily to call again to mind, his mot orrowful Ideas, that he might atisfie Thopia, whom his Friendhip ditinguiht from all the other Princes of his Court.

Thopia, (aid he, when they were come to the Palace of Croya) you will help me to bewail Ariania's, Fate, when you hall hear me, and you will confes, that if Fortune hath betowed ome Favours upon me, they have been Poyoned by many bitter dipleaures. Scanderberg gave Order none hould interrupt them, and began his Dicoure after this Manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Scanderberg.
div.p:
YOU know my Mother was Daughter to the Prince of the Triballians, and that John Catriot my Father did Reign in Epirus, and Albania; he was envy'd for his Valour by Amurat, who rendered himelf Formidable in Greece; after he had been the Terror in Aia; Catriot forced to yield to the wiftnes of his properous Fortune, made Peace with him, and ent my three Brothers and me for Hotages, to Adrianople. Vorana my Mother, keeping till by her elf four Daughters, to wipe off her Tears: She expected much from my Birth, by reaon of a Dream, which he had when he was Big of me; She Dreamed he was Delivered of a Serpent, o great; that he covered all Epirus, his head did reach to Turkey, which he wallow'd up, and he did dip his Tail in the Sea towards Venice. Catriot having heard the Relation of this Dream from Vorona, aured her he hould bring forth a Man fatal to the Turks, and ueful to Chritendom. Nevertheles I was delivered into the hands of the firt, Nothing but the
regard of the afety of his Dominions, could ever have brought him to this Reolution, I being but eight years old, all my Brothers were Elder than I; this Age expoed me to the Ceremonies of the Turks, wherein they changed my Name, that was George, into that of Scanderberg, which is as much in the Turkih Tongue, as Alexander Lord, concerning my Brothers, their Riper Age free'd them from this Violence.

The Sultan who had a good Opinion of my youth, took all the imaginable care, to make me an Honet Gentleman: The unfortunate Aradin was made my Governour, and never man performed his Duty, with more Zeal and Diligence. But tho' his kind uage made me forget, that I was beholding for it to a Slave, yet my Condition, and the firt Impreions of Religion, which I had received, could never be blotted out of my Memory.

I hall not relate to you what I did, from eight years, to ixteen. I learn'd all Exercies neceary, both for the Body and the Mind; and Aradin did all his Endeavours to inpire me with the love of Glory and Vertue. The Emperour
who took ome delight in my Sight and Converation, eem'd always pleaed with me: I had the advantage of Signalizing my elf in his preence, in the firt War wherein I was allowed to fight; and kind Fortune waiting every where upon me, being yet but nineteen years old, I was made a Sangiac by Amurat, that is to ay, a Leader, and I was truted by him, with the Command of five thouand Hores; a little while after, I was nominated a Baa, which was a Dignity that made the Sangiacs inferiour to me. I confes, my Advancement was very udden, but the Sultan, who foreaw I hould prove ueful to him, had no regard to my Youth.

In this pas I acquired more Glory in Natoly. I was feared by the Enemies, loved by the Turks, and eteemed by the Emperour; and I can hardly remember, without Bluhing, that after ome important Victories, where certainly Amurat had had a great hare, he would call me his Right Arm, his Heart, his Eye, and the Defender of his Etates. I enjoy'd all the weet Pleaures of Liberty, becaue I was look'd upon as a Turk. My Brothers
Slavery would ometimes vex me, but eeing that they did not uffer much by it, and being beides reolved to make my elf famous for the future, that was not able to put a top to my Ambition.

Heaven punihed me for this hardnes of Heart, and permitted that the Cares of Love, hould have their hare in my Heart, as well as thoe of War: Nay, hould wholly poes it. I had not gone for a long while near the Seraglio of the Women, and my Age did deprive me of thoe Carees, I was wont to receive from the Loveliet Sultanees: I felt in my heart, neither Averion nor love for their Acquaintance. And in this quiet State of indifference, I pent in ome Exercies very pleaant to the Emperour, that leaure we injoy'd at Adrianople: Thoe that were then mot in favour with him, were Muelman, Botangi Bai, or great Gardener, Mutapha, Baa of the Sea, and Orcan, the now Grand Viier. They poes'd infinite Riches, and tately Palaces, and their Families lived in great Splendour. Muelman prevailed over the others, becaue in all times and in all places, he had a free acces to
the Sultan, his Cloet, his Counel, and his Gardens were equally opened to him: Proud of thee advantages, he entertain'd other Courtiers o coldly, that he eem'd to depie them, but becaue I was loved by Amurat, and he deired to keep in his Favour, I did not find the ame reception as the ret. I had a Natural averion againt him, but I had learnt Diimulation, in a Court, where that Art was o neceary.

About this time there came to Adrianople a Tartar Prince, whom Curioity had brought thither, the like man had never been een before, he was of a prodigious height; being a foot taller than any of the ret of the Turks. Tho' he was Proud, and Rude, yet he was received like a Prince, by Amurat; it was reported he was famous over all Tartary for his Exploits; and he had never fought without Victory; proud of his own Reputation, he little regarded others civility; unfortunately for him, he contradicted me in any thing that I aid; we were ued to talk about Warlike Matters, and one day he was o preumptuous, as to tell me that the Victory over twenty uch Men as me,
would be no difficult attempt for him; being impatient, I defied him to fight me in a Duel, in the Emperour's ight. The Tartar was amazed at my boldnes, and accepted of the Challenge: Amurat, who feared the los of my Life, oppoed it: But I craved his leave o intantly, that at lat he conented to it.

The eeming unequality between my Adverary and me, affrighted all thoe who loved me, and I was likely the only man who was not alarmed: The Field for the Fight, was appointed in a pacious piece of ground, which lay over againt the Seraglio. The Emperour gave leave to the Sultanees, and Slaves, to get upon the Towers, to ee this Spectacle; and other Women, whoe Houes look'd upon that place, had the ame Licene.

At lat the hour appointed for the Fight came, and we appeared before a numberles multitude of Spectators. The Tartar began to jeer me bitterly, for my Age and Weaknes, but it was not long before I punihed him for it, and my blows were o fortunate, that after an hours Reitance, he expired in the ight of all the Aembly. There were never heard o many Acclamations
of joy among the Turks, as after my Victory; they eteem'd it a prodigy, and I was lookt upon with great Repect: I carry'd the Giant's Sword to the Emperour's Feet, who imbraced me, and tho' ome Perons envy'd me for the Honour of that day, thoe that were the Wiet, followed eaily Amurat's Example.

The Tartars took away their Mater's Corps, of which they dipoed as they pleaed; and for my part, I followed the Sultan to the Seraglio; the Prince Mahomet, his eldet Son, had received from Heaven ome eminent Parts, which had been cultivated to a great advantage; we lived very freely between us, and tho' one could not ee that tore of incere Friendhip, which tyes cloely two hearts together, yet we were not indifferent one to another; he praied my Action, and civily congratulated me for it.

That ame night to avoid the Crowd, of which I was already weary, we went together, at the Moon-Shine, upon the Sea Shore, jut behind the Seraglio of the Women; after we had walk'd a long while, in a very pleaant place, incompaed one way by the River, and
towards the Seraglio with a Hedge o thick, that it rendred the Gardens more inacceible, than any trong wall. We were ready to retire, when a Charming Voice, Sung ditinctly thee words in the Greek Tongue.

q.l: Since here a Captive, void of all relief,
I bend beneath the weight of deadly Grief;
Why, cruel Love, do't thou increae my pains,
And add new Slavery to my former Chains?

div.p:
The ound of this Voice pas'd through my Ears, to my very Heart. I had never felt before any tender motions, and my free and indifferent Soul was capable of any impreion. That! Song was repeated many times: Mahomet hearkned to it with as much attention as my elf, we knew well there were in the Seraglio many Fair Sultanees, and Lovely Slaves, whom Europe, and Aia, had offered; but they were altogether unknown to us: One hath never the more Priviledge in the Seraglio, for being either the Sultan's Son, or his Favourite; for their jealouie is o careful, in hiding what they deign for their Pleaures, that unles kind Fortune
favours a man, he can never come to know it.

The Prince, and I having heard this Charming Voice, we knew the peron who had ung it, was not alone, becaue another began to peak in Greek, but with a Barbarous pronunciation, Does that Song concern you, aid he to another, and have you lot your Heart in this place, where we ee but unpleaant Objects? Suppoe what you aid was true; anwered another, it would be a hard matter for my Heart to explain its thoughts in a Song; you have deired me to Sing, and I have done it: How happy are you, Ariania, to keep your Heart o free, and repreent anothers Ditemper, without fear of being infected with it; how happy are you, but how unfortunate is Selimana? You are the Object of the Sultan's mot tender Affection, anwered Ariania, and that is the only thing that may well atisfie you, in this Everlating Retirement. What can you deire more, Madam, ince you are the Soveraign Mitres of him, who can dipoe of all? Tho' Ambition is well pleaed with that advantage, continued Selimana, ighing, a Soul as nice as mine cannot be contented; and if you had ever been in Love, you
would quickly apprehend my meaning. Alas, Madam, I have had o many Misfortunes in my Life, that I willingly renounce to that Experiment, reply'd Ariania, with a Charming Sweetnes; well, interrupted Selimana, ince you do not know the caue of my uffering, at leat do not condemn it. A power which I cannot reit, forces me to utter this Secret without bluhing. I love, I love, Ariania, the Prince Scanderberg, and his Victory over the Tartar, is not the only one he has got to day; he has eem'd to my Eyes as Lovely, as he was formidable to his Enemy, and that hort pace of time, has aured to him the poeion of my heart for ever.

I cannot relate to you Selimana's Kindnes without bluhing: But you mut be acquainted with it, that you may the better undertand how amazed the young Sultan and I were. I was loved without knowing by whom, and uch a man as I might have been well pleaed with the Idea of this Adventure; but beides that, Selimana eem'd too paionate to deerve my Heart; he was a Sacred Object for me, being the beloved Sultanes of Amurat, I was more taken with Ariania's Modety, and tho' I did not wih her o paionate
as the other, I could have deired he had not been inenible.

Some noie made them retire; the Prince drew nearer me, when he heard them no longer, and claping his Arm about my Neck, whatever good Opinion you entertain of your elf, aid he, did you think, Scanderberg, that Mars, and Love, hould intend to betow their Favours upon you at the ame time? My Lord, reply'd I miling, if we had more Freedom at Adrianople, I would tell you that this adventure is but a ham. You ee, added Mahomet, that there is nothing but what is Natural in it; the hour, the place, and the peron who poke, in a word, all things witnes your good Fortune, and you have nothing to do, but to rejoice. Alas, My Lord, aid I, though my Heart was uceptible enough, to fall o eaily in Love, I hould never forget what I owe to the Sultan. Selimana may be a charming Peron, what he aid may flatter me, but Amurat is Emperor, and worthy of my Loyalty. You think, reply'd Mahomet, that a great Zeal for his Paion, will make me betray yours. No, My Lord, interrupted I omething hatily, I know you are generous, and dicreet, and I peak what I think. We went then into
the Seraglio, and we parted at the ame time.

I did never go to Bed without eeing Aradin; that day pleaed with the Honours I had received, he did not fail to be in my Chamber; as becaue I had no acquaintance in the Seraglio of the Women, and all things were changed there, ince my Infancy, I asked him everal quetions, which urpried him. I inquired of him concerning Selimana; he anwered me, that he was always the dearet Object of Amurat's Love, who had preferred her to all things, and he drew her Picture with great carefulnes: After that, I asked him about Ariania; and my Curioity about a Slave, who probably was unknown to me, eem'd the more urpriing to him. I don't know, Scanderberg, aid he to me, what is your Deign, but I can aure you, that among all the Women in the World, I think there is none more Lovely, than Ariania; with a perfect Beauty he poees a wonderful Wit and Virtue, and I cannot but wonder, that the Emperour has not yet cat his Eyes upon her: I hearken'd to Aradin, with a trouble which I had never felt before; what ever he aid about Ariania, were ••
many pleaant wounds to my heart, and I may ay, I was in Love, before I had een whom I loved; after a long Converation, I thought I could not hide it from Aradin; he was afflicted at it, and knowing how dear Selimana was to the Sultan, and his jealous, and violent Temper, he ued his utmot care to make me undertand, how dangerous to me uch a concurrence would prove. I aured him, I had no dipoition to love Selimana, however I dicovered not my thoughts concerning Ariania, but paed the whole night in fancying her to my elf, as lovely, as the Eunuch had decribed her; I found not my elf the following day, as I had been hitherto; is it poible that Ariania hould be prepoeed with ome tender Inclination, aid I ighing, and can my Heart, which he takes from me, hope any comfort from her? I had no ooner uttered thoe words, but I found them unworthy of a man, whoe only Ambition was to be great. I knew that violent Paions were look'd upon as a weaknes, and my Love for an unknown Object, eem'd to me trange and worthy; nevertheles, it was formidable,
and I could not conquer it as I had done the Tartar.
I was forced to open my Heart to Aradin, who condemned me to think never upon her, ince I could not hope to have any Converation with her.

There happen'd then an extraordinary thing at Adrianople, and which is eldome een among the Turks: The Sultan of Egypt had ent a magnificent Embaie; and ome rich Preents to Amurat, who to hew his Grandure to Strangers, in the eat of his Empire, gave them a publick Audience, that day the Women went from their Seraglio, to that of the Sultan's adorned with the mot precious things the Eat could afford, Selimana, the beloved, as I told you before, appeared hining with her Natural Beauty, and abundance of Ornaments; She was follow'd by a hundred, in the ame Splendour, and by an infinite number of young Slaves, dreed with les Art, but certainly worthy of another Condition: To make this Spectacle eem the greater, they wore golden Chains, and they had been loaded with Eences, and Baskets full of Flowers, which
they pread in a great Hall, at whoe end, the Sultanees sat upon rich Cuhions, thee Slaves tood round about them, and the Emperour ate upon a Splendid Throne, whoe teps were occupy'd by his chiefet Officers.

After this manner, Thopia, we aw the Secret Court of Amurat, when the Turks and Egyptians had a free acces to the Hall. Selimana ate in a higher place than the others, and her Beauty, as well as her Rank, ditinguih'd her from the ret: But among the Slaves who were round about her, the young Ariania neglected, and bluhing, for appearing before o many witnees, in a condition o unworthy of her, was remarkable, in pight of her elf, for her Charms. I could not know her as being Ariania; but my heart took notice of her, as of an Object which it was reolved to adore. And according to what I had conceived of her, upon Aradin's Relation, I wihed Arania, and that Slave might be the ame; upon that account I abandoned my elf to the Paion that poees me, and which will never end.

I hall not relate to you what was done there, having taken no notice of
the Ceremony; Ariania only had all my looks and my attention, neither did I mind whether Selimana cat her eyes upon me, as caring little for her Favour.

I ran to Aradin as oon as the Sultanees and the Slaves were retired. Love which firt had engaged me by the adventure I had had with Mahomet, made me feel now all its power: The Eunuch was amazed at the violence of my Paion, and was almot angry. My dear Scanderberg, aid he to me, you know me well enough, not to quetion the incerity of my advices; what can you hope from an affection, whoe conequences mut needs be unfortunate? Fortune condemns Ariania to be a Slave for ever; will you confine the Glory of your life in an hopeles Love? And don't you deerve to be blamed for the unreaonablenes of the deign? I confes, Ariania is a Charming Peron, and according to all probability her Birth is not mean: But what can you hope from her as long as he is in the Seraglio, where all things breathe only for Amurat's Pleaure? Can you fetch out Ariania in pight of o many Perons, who watch always to atisfie the Emperour's jealouie? And will you not deerve
his hatred, for breaking thee Laws, the leat violation of which deerves Death; reflect upon your elf, Scanderberg, forget Ariania, who can ruine you. Conider you are a Prince deigned for extraordinary things, and covered already with a Glory which you ought to preerve.

This Dicoure of Aradin, which his affection created, confounded my reaon, but did not perwade my heart: My Love for Ariania was too trong, and it could not be prevailed on by his Advices, no more than by my own Reflections; he perceived well my ad Condition, but eeing it was impoible to alter my mind, he exhorted me not to rule my Conduct according to my blind Paion, but to have a pecial regard to Amurat's Severity, and to take my meaures accordingly.

I felt all the griefs of Love, as oon as I knew Ariania; the impoibility of eeing her was to me a mot cruel pain, depair often makes us light thoe things we deire to obtain, but the difficulties I met with here, did but inflame me the more.

As if the Obtacles before mentioned, bad not been enough, there aroe againt me three formidable Rivals. The Emperour,
who had never before look'd upon Ariania, found her o Beautiful the day of the Publick Audience of the Egyptians, that Selimana eemed to him les Charming. Prince Mahomet, who had not till then entertain'd any other thought, but the fear of the common Fate of the Princes of his Blood, and who had carried himelf o well, towards the Sultan, as not to give him any jut caue of Anger or Jealouie, paid to Ariania's Beauty, what was due to her from all tender Hearts. And Muelman, who ought to have reted atisfy'd with the amorous intrigues, which either his Inclination or good Fortune had procured him, look'd upon her with the ame eyes as we did.

I knew not for a long while their thoughts, and I was very careful to hide mine. Mahomet became melancholy; and for my part, I loved Solitude o much, that I could carce cat my eyes upon thoe things which formerly had o much pleaed me; we neglected our Warlike Exercies, we minded no more thoe Pleaures which we had been o deirous of before, and Solitude was the only thing we ought after: All admiion in the Seraglio of the Women being
forbidden to us, we were continually in the paages to it; where ever my Love guided me, I did meet there Mahomet: Muelman was happier than we, his Employ, whoe Authority is almot unlimited, did give him acces where we could not go, and we may think he made ue of his advantages.

As I was ued to pend mot part of the day and night about thoe places, which hide Ariania from my ight, I did ometimes forget my elf there. One night I tarried o long in the Emperour's Garden, which was next to that of the Women, that the Gates were hut up: All the Botangi's had retired, no body was up any longer in the Seraglio, no light appeared there, and I was fain to tay there till day, after I had endeavoured to no purpoe to get out towards the Sea.

As I was withdrawing in a retired place, to pend there the ret of the night, I aw a man croing the great Flower Garden, and marching towards me with all poible hate: By avoiding him, I had confet my elf guilty, therefore going towards him, I perceived it was the Emperour. What do you do here, Scanderberg, aid he to me, with a evere
Countenance? being bred up in Our Palaces, and well intructed with our Cutoms, ought you to hew this Example of boldnes to o many Perons, who can make an ill ue of it, and have you ome ecret deign againt my Ret, my Life, or my Authority? I have nothing to ay to thy Highnes for my Jutification, anwered I, and I appear guilty enough, to deerve thy indignation; but I mut ay this, that a melancholy humour is the caue of the fault for which thou blamet me, and I wear I have tarryed here minding not the place where I was. You are o dear to me, reply'd the Emperour, that I am concern'd with all your orrows, and if you have any reaon for any, not only I forgive you this fault, but hall do my endeavours to atisfie you. Thine Highnes, aid I, is too kind, and ought not to trouble it elf about o mall trifles; the want of Employment is the caue of my orrow, and thy Highnes, leaving nothing to do for us, makes my young Courage grumble at its being idle. You have done enough to deire Peace, and enjoy ome Ret, reply'd the Sultan, but if your Valour wants exercie, I promie you ome. Go home quietly, and expect from me uch Employments, as are worthy of a Hero, who intends to urpas all the Ottomans.

I made a very humble bow to the Emperour, glad I had pacify'd him, and went away as he directed me; but that Night was to bring forth other adventures. Prince Mahomet, brought there by the ame motives as I, had been alo hut in, and we aw him coming towards us, thinking we were ome Botangi's, or Eunuchs: Is this a fit time for you to be here, aid the angry Emperour to him, and are you my Son, only to hew your elf unworthy of being o? The young Prince was truck with thee words, he aw me, and thought concerning me the ame thing I did concerning him. I have inned againt my own will, My Lord, anwered he to the Sultan, but I protet to thy Highnes I hall come hither no more. A third man who did teal behind the Hedge more lily than we had done, hinder'd the Sultan's reply; he did go towards the Womens Lodgings, a place which had always eem'd upicious to Amurat, but chiely now in the beginning of his new Paion; but his fear and vexation increaed when he heard Ariania's fine voice, with which he was already acquainted, ing thee words.

q.l: Go on, oberve the Dictates of your Love,
The Favours of the hady night improve.
Suppres thee ighs which from diorders flow,
And let your noble Flame yet higher grow,
Yield him your heart, his pleaing rules obey,
Who is a God, and does direct your way.

div.p: The Sultan felt then all the powers of jealouie, eteeming that Song to be the ignal: we were guilty all three, and never did an innocent Adventure afford greater caue of upicion to a paionate Lover: He ran to the third Adventurer, and knew him preently to be Muelman, whom Ariania's voice had topt.

None of us was a contemptible peron, and tho' Mahomet and I had ome advantages above Muelman, by reaon of our Youth, and natural parts, yet his Authority in the Gardens might be of a great ue to a forward man. Tho' the Botangi Baa had ome priviledges and few et hours, yet Amurat thought him more guilty than us. Muelman, aid he to him, with that pride which is natural to all the Sultans, what brings
you hither at an hour, when no duty requires your preence? Was it to introduce you to the Sultanees, that a Slave ung jut now, and do you leave your houe only to come and trouble me in mine?

Muelman was not amazed at this upbraiding, he is Naturally bold, and anwering without any commotion, I thought, my Lord, reply'd he, I could not have too much Zeal for thine Highnes, and that all the hours of the day and night, were free for my Loyalty; by thy Kindnes I command in the Gardens, but I know how to tay in mine, as oon as I hall perceive that my Services are upected. I believe, aid the Emperor, I hall not be able to unriddle this Mitery; I will moderate my own Temper, let us retire, and let us be more careful for the future: So we retired into the Seraglio: I don't quetion but Muelman upected both the Prince's Love and mine. Amurat whom his reflect thoughts had brought to the Garden at that hour againt his Cutome, doubled the Guards towards the Seraglio of the Women, and gave more evere orders to the Eunuchs, which ome faithfully oberved.

Aradin upbraided me the next day for my wandring: We concluded Mahomet
and Muelman were my Rivals, and hoping to cure me, he aured me the Emperour was deeply in Love with Ariania: That Paion could not detroy mine, tho' it ruined all my hopes, I feared neither the Prince nor Muelman, whoe condition was not better than mine: But I ought to fear all things from the Sultan, whoe inclinations were violent, and whoe will nothing was able to reit. I ighed for this with Aradin, I became more circumpect before the Prince; and avoiding the Gardens, contented my elf with the Entertainment my Melancholy Thoughts enjoy'd upon the Sea Shoar.

I undertood one day, that the Emperour was going to bathe with ome Sultanees, in a little Iland, from Adrianople about an hours journey; he was ued to take ecretly uch Patimes, and then he would put off for a while all orts of Gravity; his Galley was o hut, that the Sultanees could neither ee nor be een; it was led by ome Botangi's, and Muelman by vertue of his place was at the head of them, but that honour procured him no advantage, ince he could ee nothing but his Botangi's.

But my Jealouie was o trong, that I went all along the Sea a very great way from Adrianople, and cating my looks as far as they could reach, I aw omething over the water, carryed away by the tream: I thought I perceived a Vail, and believing it might be a Woman ready to be drowned, I threw my elf preently into the water, and uing my little Skill, I wam with all poible diligence, and took really into my Arms a woman, who was almot choak'd.

I doubled my efforts to get to the Shore, and as oon as I was there, I perceived it was Ariania: You may judge, Dear Thopia, what was my grief when I aw the only thing that was dear to me, in uch a lamentable condition, Merciles Fate, cry'd I, ought you to have offered her to me in uch a condition? O fair, but unwie Ariania, why did you eek your death, in o little important a Pleaure? This tranport of mine did not hinder me from aiting her. I lifted her head, and bending a little the ret of her body, abundance of water ruhed out of it, and within a hort while, he recovered her Breath; this relief called again the
natural heat which eem'd to have foraken her, and drove away part of my Allarms, after a deep igh, he open'd her Eyes, and eeing her elf alone with a man, having but a thin gown on, he was willing to change her poture. Knowing her Deign, and deirous to pleae her, I let her et down upon the Gras, and eeing he was able to undertand me; Fair Ariania, aid I, that Fate which hath expoed your Life, hath been favourable to my Affection, but let not this adventure trouble you, ince Scanderberg would ooner loe his Life, than his repect towards your Peron.

Ariania ighed twice or thrice, and was ome while without anwering me, but at lat he reply'd: Tho' my Life be not dear to me, My Lord, I am not the les beholding to you; if you had not been o generous, you had freed me from many Misfortunes; but you could not have guet my condition. I was as much moved with Ariania's words, as with her languihing Charms. I know not what Fate Heaven deigns for you, but I hall think my elf happy for ever, ince I have been erviceable to you; in another time, and under another Government, I hould take other meaures, and hould not let you
know my Love, till my Services and Repect had ufficiently demontrated it; and deerved your conent; but as things tand now, how is it poible to ee you in a Palace, where we can have no admiion? and how can one peak with you, ince it is in vain to hope to come near you? I Love you, I am forced to acquaint you with it, and if this free Confeion renders me guilty, I hall never repine at my Punihment, I was the ame before I had een you, and I adored your Vertue, without knowing your Peron. What Dicoure is this, My Lord, interrupted Ariania, with a charming Sweetnes? Is this to try me? Do you conider that I am a Slave, ubject to the Emperour of the Turks, loaded with Chains by Selimana, and who likely hall not ee you any more in all her life time? as for your preent condition, aid I, it is an injury of Fortune, which may eaily be repaired, and if you deire to put an end to your Captivity, do but trut me, and, follow me. What can you do, Scanderberg, cry'd that fair Captive? You have Valour enough to overcome Amurat's Enemies, but you are not trong enough to deliver me from his Tyraany.

I had done, may be, more than Ariania
could hope for, if on one ide Mahomet, who had followed my teps, had not arrived near us, and on the other, we had not een the Emperour's Galley, returning to Contantinople grievouly afflicted, to have een Ariania carried away by the Stream wherein he had fallen, advancing too far in the Bath: Too happy Scanderberg, aid the jealous Prince to me, why don't you content your elf with Selimana's Favours? I was vexed at this Dicoure, and Ariania Bluhed: I aw the young Sultan had no mind to oblige me, but I had not time to let him know my anger. Amurat, in a kind of Depair, whoe eyes ought Ariania every where, perceived us upon the Shore, and came to deprive me of what I had acquired, with the hazard of my own life: He told me confuedly, I had done him a good piece of Service; and Ariania, paing into the Galley, aured me by a kind look, he was not inenible of what I had done for her. I cannot expres what my amorous heart uffered at this parting. Tho' I had feared it, yet I thought it would not be o udden, and I could hardly hide my orrow.

p.U:
aid Mahomet to me, we are both in Love with Ariania, but tho' the Laws render our Fortunes equal, by forbidding us from eeing her, yet you have ome advantages that may comfort you for that Misfortune. I could deny to you, what are my Sentiments, concerning Ariania, anwered I, ince any generous man ought to have done what I did, and that I knew not it was he, when I went about to erve her, but I cannot diemble, and I mut confes that I love her. I perceived, My Lord, you were my Rival, and a jealous Rival too, who cared not to oblige me, when you poke to me concerning Selimana. Can you wonder, I hould promote my own heart's interet, reply'd the young Sultan? Ariania is not beloved by the Emperour, and were you not my Rival, may be I hould have none. You are mitaken, Mahomet, added I; the Emperour has changed his Love: What is he in Love with Ariania, reply'd he? Yes, aid I. Alas! continued he ighing, what hope can flatter us? and uppoe we hould follow the advices of the mot violent jealouie, what advantage will that afford us? Then
we entered into Adrianople, where the Emperour was already returned, and we put an end to our Dicoure.

div.p:
I met Aradin who was looking for me, knowing what had pat. Having done o much for my peron, aid I to him, embracing him, will you attempt nothing for my ret? will you abandon me to thoe orrows, that Love threatens me with? and will all your acquaintance in the Seraglio prove fruitles? I ought to employ them only for the Sultan's Service, reply'd Aradin, and my Zeal can afford you but a weak aitance; tho' you are infinitely dear to me, I am forced to ee you uffer, without attempting any thing in your behalf. I ee Amurat is mad becaue you have een Ariania, he fears without knowing why, and we hall become Slaves to his jealouie. Is that your way of comforting me, dear Aradin, cry'd I? But what will you have, reply'd the Eunuch, and what can one do under a Mater o powerful, and o formidable as Amurat? Do you think Ariania will be able to reit him? and uppoe he had no real Love for him, he mut till fear and obey
him. Aradin's dicoure, filled my mind with o dreadful Ideas, that I was like to dye for Grief, and he aw me o much afflicted, that he could not deny me the Favour of carrying a Letter from me to Ariania. 'Tis likely I hall pay dear enough, aid he, for what I am going to do for you; but I hall eaily comfort my elf, if you are fully perwaded of my incere Friendhip. I embraced Aradin, and having wrote what Love dictated to me, I delivered the Billet to his care: There are but thee few words in it.

body.head: The Prince Scanderberg to Ariania.
body.p: I Could wih, fair Ariania, for my heart's ret, that you were les amiable, or les beloved; pity me for having o many misfortunes to uffer, and o many Enemies to overcome: You cannot but be orry for my condition, ince for the reward of my Paionate and Faithful Heart, which I preent you with, the only thing I ask, is the leave of telling you, I hall adore you for ever.

div.p: The officious Aradin took all the imaginable care to come near Ariania, but he could not that day, he was o wearied by her lat Misfortune, that he was forced to keep her Bed. The Emperour took no longer any care to hide his new Paion, but owned it publickly. Ariania had a private Apartment for her elf; and Selimana, tormented with other cares, was not enible at firt of the hame of being foraken.

But Ariania was inenible of the marks of the Sultan's Love, o much wihed for by the other Women of the Seraglio. Amurat ighed like other Lovers at the firt growth of his Paion; after that he would fain go farther: But Ariania was equally dipleaed with his Sighs and Haughtines, and hewed a repugnancy which he little expected, and which was look'd upon by him as a Prodigy in a Girl of her Age and condition; the more becaue his violent deires had never met before with uch a reitance.

Aradin, a zealous and diligent Friend, perform'd his errand as oon as he could; he found Ariania alone, melancholy, and thinking doubtles upon
what he was to uffer from the Sultan. Fair Ariania, aid he to her, all moments are here precious, and I ought not to neglect them. Scanderberg, famous for his Valour, and remarkable for his rare and great Qualities, (forgive me, Thopia, if I ue Aradin's words, to avoid all digreions) Scanderberg, ay I, kept far from you by a barbarous Law, deires you might know his Zea and Contancy; and to that purpoe he is forced to make ue of this innocent means. Then the Eunuch offered her the Billet: But he who knew not our intimate friendhip thought he was come to try her. Thee Intreagues are not allowed in the Seraglio, anwered he; we might pay both dear enough for them; and your Mater is not o kind a Prince as to permit them. Leave off therefore this Playing, which cannot but dipleae me, and may prove fatal to your elf: And believe, that I care neither to love nor to be loved. You may upect me of Perfideounes, replyed Aradin, eeing it is o common among the Turks, and becaue I am altogether unknown to you. But, Ariania, do not entertain uch a thought concerning me; and do not wrong o
far the Prince Scanderberg; he loves you, and you cannot, but with a Cruelty blame-worthy, deny him the favour to read what he writes to you. Ariania, after a long reitance, took at lat the Paper, and kept her eyes fix'd upon it a coniderable while; o that likely he read it more than once. Aradin oberved her, and told me afterwards, that he had perceiv'd in her looks a trouble which favoured me, that he had ighed, and eem'd to feel ome tender motions in her heart; and conidering her and my own condition, he had aid, alas, Aradin, what can the Prince Scanderberg expect from me, who can dipoe of nothing, and find my elf bound in that unfortunate place where my ill Fortune detains me? All his deire, replyed Aradin, is, you would permit him to love you, and that your kindnes might be concerned in all his misfortunes. Suppoe I hould do what he deires, added Ariania, would his condition be the happier? Bid him, ooner forget me, and if he finds in me any thing that deerves his affection, let him conider, that all orts of Converation is forbidden us; let him take care, not to attempt any hazardous
enterprize that may either undo him or endanger my elf; let him be careful chiefly of his own life. Ariania, interrupted Aradin, is your heart o much concerned for his life as to deire its preervation? Ask me no uch quetions, replyed the fair Slave bluhing, and do only what I bid you. Ariania, aid the officious Aradin, one word from your hand would do more with him than any thing I can tell him. You ask for too much, replyed Ariania, and you know your elf, I ought not to do what you deire; that all things are dangerous here, and that very often the mot ecret Actions become publick. I tremble even now for reaon of this converation; be gone, Aradin, and leave me to my dreadful orrow. I leave you to the Sultan's love, replyed Aradin. Cruel misfortune of my Life, and caue of all my Mieries, cryed Ariania; how dearly have I paid for that love which I abhor? and what orrows I am like to uffer upon its account? Some body coming, obliged them to part. Ariania kept my Letter, and Aradin came to me to acquaint me with what had pas'd.

The Emperour's love was too violent not to be followed by an extraordinary jealouie; his upicious increaed exceively; and conidering Ariania's coldnes, he thought that either her heart was not free when he came to the Seraglio, or that ince he had fallen in love. His meeting me in the Gardens, my good fortune upon the Seahoar, and my deep melancholy, which I was no more able to hide, rais'd great upicions in his mind. And though my condition was but little different from Muelman's, or the Prince's, yet I eem'd to him more formidable than they, by reaon of my good Fortune: He oberv'd carefully all my teps, took notice of my Eyes, which were always turned towards the Seraglio, explained to himelf the meaning of my troubles, and of my Sighs; and in a word, did not quetion but I was in love. You may eaily conjecture whether it was an eaie matter for me to attempt any thing, being watch'd by uch an Argus. Aradin, who perceived his jealouie, was continually adviing me how I ought to teer my Conduct, and in this uneaie condition I pent many ad and ueles days.

But, Thopia, I was not the only Man who was troubled. Muulman loved exceedingly Ariania: The ame Paion wholly poes'd Mahomet; and Selimana being foraken by the Emperor, began to be enible of the injury done her Beauty, and thought the only way to be revenged, was to get a new Lover.

There is always a prodigious number of Eunuchs in the Seraglio, whoe duty is to oberve the Sultanees, and to erve them, and thoe are pickt out from among the ugliet. Selimana's favour had gained her the zeal of the mot coniderable of them: Amaldan had always tuck to her interet; and ince Amurat's new Paion gave her time to mind her own, he manag'd o well the Eunuch's Zeal, that he was willing to do her any Service.

Amaldan was about forty years old, he was black and ugly, but witty and bold, and in a word, a fit Confident to erve Selimana: It had look'd a little odd, if he had acquainted me without any more ado with Selimana's tender affection. She knew not what the Prince and I had heard, and therefore he could make no ue of that Adventure; had he directly written to me, it was
likely my Heart had not been plead with that freedom; he therefore wholly relyed upon Amaldan's wit: Having been bred up a Schollar, he undertood Greek perfectly well, and was well nough acquainted with the niceties of Poetry; he thought therefore his bet way at firt, was to hew me ome witty Veres; and having made ome fit for his purpoe, he accoted me upon a Terras in the great Seraglio's Gardens where, in a melancholly Humour, I was looking upon the Stream that water'd the foot of the Walls. Who could believe, my Lord, aid he to me, that a Prince of your Age and Parts would eek olitary places without being in love? Was your Heart free, you would not hun with o much care other Men's Converation. I beg your pardon, my Lord, for my boldnes; but your natural bounty will excue this freedom, which is not ordinarily ued towards Perons of your rank, but in whatever condition you are, either free, or not, thoe that honour you as much as I do, ought to do always their endeavours to divert you. I bluhed, hearing Amaldan, peak thus, fearing let he hould upect omething. My Lord, aid he then, one
does not bluh except he hath ome reaon for it, and this commotion proceeds likely from your Heart. But without piercing too far into a Secret which I ought to reverence, give me leave to conult you upon a nice point. And then he offered me ome Veres, which I could not deny to read, and which I remember yet, they were thoe:

q.l: Love, like a dangerous Tyrant till appears,
His fancy'd Laws ound harh to tender Ears.
Women, if fair, we mut avoid, they ay,
Like fatal Rocks at Sea, which oft detroy.
Such feign'd Advice puts out the glowing Fire,
And turns the edge of ev'ry brisk Deire.
The Fears of Shipwraek thro' the fancy rove,
And fright the Youth from off the Seas of Love.
But when he ees the way before him's clear,
When he is choe and loved, what needs he fear?
If he would then enjoy a happy State,
He mut give up his yielding Heart to Fate:
When he is Conqueror own'd, then Arms are vain;
To ue the Conquet is the weetet gain.
The greater then his Zeal does prove,
The more's the glory of his Love.

div.p:
I lik'd them well enough, and I read them more than once; but I never upected the meaning of them. Amaldan was glad I was pleaed with them, and thought it was now time for him to trut me with his Secret. Is it not true, my Lord, that Love is commonly drawn after a trange manner? and that, if we will hearken to the Wits, it is a dreadful Monter, which ought carefully to be avoided? I confes, it appears unpleaant to thoe that have nothing that renders them worthy to be beloved; but I imagine thouands of Charms in the incere and tender love of two Hearts. I mut confes, aid I to Amaldan, that your Veres and your Opinion eem to me to be in the right; but I am o little vered in Love Matters, that I am no competent Judge of its Effects. My Lord, reply'd the Eunuch, when you
pleae you may be a great proficient therein, and I know a certain way for that purpoe. I cannot diemble with a Prince, as dicreet as you are. I'll tell you therefore, you are loved by Selimana, Amurat's beloved Sultanes; he acquaints you, what way it is bet for you to follow, by her order I peak to you, and you ought not to be dicouraged at the Seraglio's Maximes, ince I can overcome the greatet Difficulties. I did not expect uch a Complement from Amaldan, which did not anwer my Inclinations, and I was a little while without anwering him. You bring your elf into no danger by your freedom, aid I at lat to him. I take it for a token of your Eteem and Friendhip, nor am I willing to make an ill ue of it. Selimana may be fair and kind, but Amurat is a formidable Prince, and my Loyalty obliges me to all orts of repects. You don't peak, reply'd the Eunuch miling, like a young Prince favour'd by Love, but like a fearful Politician, or a moroe Philoopher. This modety which ought to be praied in a Dervie, eems to me in you the tranget things in the world; what can all Amurat's power do, ince your beloved Scanderberg's Pleaures
eaily obtained, loe much of their weetnes? Beides, was I not certain to erve you, I am not o much out of love with my own life, as to expoe my elf to an unavoidable Death: Let me then be your Guide, and trut me with the carrying on of your Intregue. All Amaldan's fair words could not peruade me to it. I was not willing to expoe my elf to o many Dangers for Selimana's ake, and I alledged till in my Defence, Cutom, and my Loyalty to the Emperor.

Amaldan did not acquaint the Sultanes with the unhappy iue of his firt Negotiation, let he hould drive her into Depair; her hatred againt Amurat increaed, as his love for Ariania; he was capable of any violent Action, had not Amaldan allay'd her Rage.

Prince Mahomet, who eem'd to act nothing, and Muulman, whoe proceedings were very ecret, had nevertheles ome private Intelligences, and gain'd ome Friends in the Seraglio. Covetounes is o natural to the Turks, that Interet often makes void the everity of their Laws. Botangi Bai being a rich Man, gained by his liberality almot all the Eunuchs; and except Aradin whoe
Honety was proof againt all temptation, the ret yielded eaily to his Gold; having a free occaion in the Gardens, he could freely Convere with them; he intruted the cunning Amaldan with his Paion for Ariania. Another had been tarted at this Propoition. But Amaldan harken'd to it without the leat Commotion, and his exaggerating to the grand Gardner, the difficulties they hould meet with, was only to et an higher value upon his Services.

You may judge, Thopia, thereby, how Pernicious is idlenes; had the Eunuchs a different Employment from that of oberving the Women in the Seraglio, they hould never apply themelves to barter their Favours.

Amaldan, who knew Ariania well enough, to perceive her good Nature, feared not in the leat to be punihed by her for his boldnes. He did Muulman's Errant, as Aradin had done mine, and repreented the Botangi Bai's Paion to her, as the only way to free her from her lavery; he did not entertain him as he had done Aradin, but with a Noble Pride, he let him undertand that it was in vain for the grand Gardner to hope any thing from
her. The covetous Amaldan was little troubled at this, and was not uch a Fool as to dicourage any body, as long as he could obtain his Ends. He reolved in pight of my elf, to bring me one Night into Selimana's company; and little olicitous of her Honour or Fortune, o he might atisfie himelf. He truted Muulman with this Secret. He told him that if he could bring me into the private Gardens, for himelf, he would get Selimana and Ariania to take a walk, which might be favourable to us, making the grand Gardner believe, that I was in love with the Sultanes, and that fear only hindred me from courting her. Muulman, who had upected I loved Ariania, was glad to undertand this Mitery, and promied to do whatever Amaldan deired.

The grand Gardner was well enough acquainted with the Maxims of the Country; the effects of which he ought to fear, but his Love prevailed over his Reaon. He found me out, as he had promied to Amaldan, and asked me, whether I was willing to walk. I could not gues his intentions, and tho' I looked upon him as my Rival, yet, at lat I followed him.

We took many turns in the Seraglio's Garden, and the Botangi Bai, who was well acquainted with all the byways, brought me into that of the Women, through a door which we found open'd; I was not enible at firt of my wandring, but coming near a labyrinth, which I had not een ince my Infancy. I was urpried to ee my elf in that place. You are mitaken, or you have a mind to ruine me, aid I to Muulman, and thee places are not free for uch perons as we. Do you think I am capable of betraying you? Anwered Muulman, and do you believe I hall not hare here the ame Fortune with you? Your preence is deired by Selimana, and her kindnes will protect you. As I was going to anwer, dipleaed with his proceedings, we aw Prince Mahomet coming, who had no more priviledge than we, and who was not there without ome Deign. He was as much urpried as we. We could not think but we were guilty all three; yet prudence would have us hide our Reentments, and had we had a mind to fall out, we had been hindered by Abaci the Eunuch, who had introduced the young Sultan, and who knew nothing
of our being there. My Lord, aid he to him, loud enough to be heard by us Ariania is coming, make ue of u •• a favourable moment. Abaci went hi • way, and Ariania, who had parte • from Selimana, came. Tho' Night deprived us of the ight of her Charms, yet by reaon of its favourable ilence we could the better hear her ight. Muulman curbed by Mahomet's preence did not enjoy the happines he hoped for. And the Prince in a maze by reaon of Abaci's dicoure, tarried in the ame place. For my part, I was alo put to a tand. Ariania at her elf down upon the gras, and thinking he was heard by no body, he let go thee ad Complaints. Unfortunate Ariania, aid he, Princes expos'd to ever lating Sufferings, what cant thou expect from Amurat? What cant thou do for Scanderberg? Did Cruel Fate take thee from Albania, to offer him here too Charming for thy Ret? Catriot, why don't you ask all the Princes of the World ome Succour, to deliver uch an Illutrious Son from thoe Hands, who likely, for a Reward of his Glorious Exploits, will one day acrifice him.

Thee Ariania's words made a deep impreion upon both our Hearts. But, Thopia, thoe two Rivals were not the only I ought to fear, a third more formidable heard them. Amurat acquainted by ome Traytor, that Soliman and Ariania were in the Garden, was urpried at it, becaue they were not ued to go there, running therefore with all poible hate, he heard what I have already told you. Perfidious Ariania, cryed he in a jealous rage, thou tellet every moment I ee thee, and tho' thou hat my mot tender Affections, yet wihet thou my Ruine. Thy imprudent Heart hath condemned Scanderberg to dye, and I will punih him for having pleaed thee, as I ought to do. I am not afraid of thy Anger, replyed the courageous Ariania, and I am o far from pacifying it, that I confirm to thee what thou hat already heard by chance. A Power above thine will defend that Prince thou intendet to Oppres, and for my part, I hall be pleaed better with Death than with thy Love.

About that time, Thopia, did the Emperor perceive us. I cannot expres his Rage to you. His Son, and
Muulmon uffered but little by it. It fell heavy only upon me. Take away that Slave, aid he, to a great many Eunuchs, and be reponible of the leat of her Actions: and for thee, aid he, turning towards me, Knave, and peridious Scanderberg, unworthy Object of Amurat's Favours, and the fatal caue of all his preent grief, go, and expect uch a death as thou deervet. If thine Injuries proceeds from thy jealouie, anwered I, I forgive them upon that account, becaue that Paion is ued to blind our Reaon. Think of my moderation what thou pleaet, but know, that had any other Man poke to me after this manner, beides thee, he hould not ecape unpunihed.

The proud Emperor harkned no longer to me. He commanded I hould be hut up in the dreadfullet Prion, thinking by what he had heard, I entertain'd ome ecret Correpondence with Ariania. As for Mahomet and Muulman, he hew'd them only an angry Countenance, without Arreting them.

Selimana ran away hearing this noie, and Amaldan was not uch a Fool as to come and hew his Face. As oon as we were out of the Gardens, Amurat
threatned the Eunuchs, and truck Terror every where. He ent the ugliet of his Seraglio to oberve the Women, and uch a vat number of them was placed in Ariania's Appartment, that all admiion there became impoible.

I was hut up in a Dungeon, without eeing Aradin, whom my misfortune was like to cat into a depair. He undertood the Adventure I have related to you, by Amaldan's means, whoe imprudence and diloyalty he much blamed. Aradin did not quetion the heavines of my grief, in uch a orrowful place, where I had o many reaons of being afflicted. Amurat upbraided him with my pretended treachery, and accued him to have bred me up in thoe, ill dipoitions, being well acquainted with hiss Temper, he yielded to the firt tranports of his rage, pretended to condemn me, and by thee means prevented his own digrace. Having till his wonted freedom, he made ue of it, he aw Ariania in pight of all her Obervers, comforted her, and obliged her to write to me, acquainting her with my deplorable condition. She did not quetion in the leat,
but I had heard her in the Garden, and therefore was the eaier reolved to it. Aradin ent me this Note by one of my Guardians.

body.head: Ariania to the Prince Scanderberg.
body.p: I Am fain to let you know I pity your misfortune, and no conideration can diwade me from it; thoe Powers that Tyrannize over you do not pare me. But, my Lord, I protet your Pains are my greatet Evils; if this aurance may comfort you, you may intirely enjoy the pleaure of it. I am concerned for your Ret, I am grieved, and even weep for your mifortunes. Tho' I dare not tell you any thing as concerning my heart, you may nevertheles think thereupon what you uppoe will the bet atisfie you. This favour Ariania begs from you,

closer.signed: Ariania, Daughter to Aranit Conino, a Prince beloved by the King your Father.

div.p:
Having read this Letter, I was no longer enible of the heavines of my Chains. I enjoyed my hearts deire. I was beloved of Ariania, born of one of the mot Illutrious Families in Albania. I knew Aranit's name, and tho'
I had but a feeble Idea of my Father's Court, yet I could remember him. It was quite impoible for me to anwer Arianta's Note. And all that I could do was to read it over a thouand times a day.

But, Thopia, Fortune, which intended to cros me, afflicted me till with new msifortunes. I learnt from that man whom Aradin had dipoed to favour me, that my Father was dead, that Amurat was incened againt me, and to poes himelf of Catriot's Dominions, had poioned my three Brothers, deigning me for another Sacrifice; but altho' he was violent to exces; he durt not detroy me, in the Preence of the Turkih Souldiers, by whom I was loved, and who began to grumble at my Captivity.

Amurat's Cruelty produced in my heart that effect which could be reaonably expected; yet I mut tell you, to jutifie my reentments, that I never projected any Deign againt him, unworthy of a Man of Courage; all that I deired, was to ee my elf free, and to declare an open War againt the proud Sultan, who regarded o little the Blood I had lot in his Service.

Whilt I was thus griev'd and perplexed, both by Nature and Love, the Turks, who had een me venture my life for their Emperour's Glory, pityed my Fate, and demanded my Liberty. Amurat deired my death, but feared the conequences thereof, and therefore was obliged by reaon of the Grumbling of the Nation, to put an end to my Captivity.

Going out of Prion, I retired to Acomat, a young Baa, and the only Man amongt the Turks, upon whoe Friendhip I did mot rely. I met there with a generous reception; he approved my Reentment, and advied me to go my elf, and upbraid the Sultan for his ungratefulnes. But I could not abide his ight, I could not think without horror on my Brothers death. My Mother's ad condition, and the mierable Life the young Princees my Siters lead in ome retired place of Albania. I heard before it was long, the violent proceedings of the Emperor's Tyranny; I had a true Relation thereof from Aradin, whom I aw by Acomat's means, he aured me alo of Ariania's kindnes towards me, and added, that tho'
the Sultan's Rage had not fall'n o heavy upon Mahomet or Muulman as upon me, yet they had marted for his Jealouie.

Tho' I was fully at liberty, I did not know what to reolve. Amurat had poes'd himelf of all my Dominions, and the only thing I could own, was my Sword; after a long Conultation with Acomat and Aradin, at lat I intended to depart, tho' I felt a great reluctancy in leaving Ariania.

Tho' I had conceived a mortal hatred againt Amurat, yet I reolved to peak to him. I met him one day, as he was going out of the Divan. He had been vexed at ome important deliberation there, and dipleaed with Ariania's continual rigour, o that one could eaily read his Rage in his Eyes. I thought, aid he, you hould make a better ue of the Liberty I granted you at Adrianople, than to offer your elf to my preence, and that your remore hould free me from the ight of uch an odious Object. This Dicoure, like the Ottoman Pride, was too outragious to me, to be born patiently. If thine ungrateful Eyes had never een me, anwered I, it is likely you had paid dear
enough for it. You are no longer an Hotage, interrupted the unjut Amurat, but a Captive, of whom the Janiaries, are to be reponible. If thou hadt conidered Hotages as acred, replyed I, thou hadt never poion'd my Brothers, and nothing can hide the Horror of this Barbarous action from Poterity. I pity thy young age, replyed the Sultan, with a cornful mile, and the trouble thou taket of decribing my Actions, deerves a fit Reward; get far from me and Ariania, and repent of having offended me. I wear to thee by our mot Holy Laws, I hall never call thee back again.

So he left me pightfully. I aw preently, that it was now time for me to depart, and to perform for my own Family, and that of Ariania what Honour required from me; it was impoible for me to ee that Charming Beauty, whom I recommended a thouand times to the care of the Affectionate Aradin.

Amurat, to cloak his injutice, and not to dioblige the Janiaries, who had declared themelves my Protectors, offered me by Orcan, his Favourite, and already Grand Viier, in the room of the deceaed Herecoli, the Command
of ome Forces, which he kept in the entrance of Aia, and ent me word, to tarry there for his Orders, thinking I hould never attempt any thing againt him, ince all the Garrions in Epirus, and Albania were filled up with Turks. Aradin did not quetion but Amurat's deign was to hut me up in ome remote Fortres. Croya it elf eemed well affected for him, notwithtanding all the Efforts of the Princes Loyal to our Interet.
But, Thopia, as I was ready to depart, eeming to accept of Amurat's proffer, Fortune procured me the happines of eeing Ariania once more.

There happenned one night a fire in the Seraglio, Muulman was upected to be the Author of it. It increaed o much, that it cat all Adrianople into a great Conternation. The Appartment of the Women began to burn, and the like Confuion was never een; they laboured but in vain to put it out in the Emperor's preence, who encouraged thoe that laboured; all the Water of the Sea, Channels, and Rivers, had never been able to ave Ariania, had I not hewed my elf more eager, and more Couragious than the ret.

You may judge how much I was affrighted at this Accident, and with what hate I ran to ait her. All the Janiaries, Spahis, and other Souldiers, and all the Officers of the Seraglio were buied in quenching the Flame, but durt not venture any farther to ave the Women threatned with a cruel Death. Amurat's fair Promies were in vain, fear rendred them all deaf to his words, and I was the only Man whom Love emboldened; I ran upon high Piles of burning Cinders to the Gallery, where the Women with the Eunuchs expected their lat hour. And mot part of them did cry after a trange rate, for fear of Death. Selimana her elf looked very pale and fearful. But Ariania preerved till her magetick and erene Countenance, and look'd upon death without the leat Commotion. As oon as Selimana perceived me, he came to trut her elf into my arms, but he found them not opened. Aradin, aid I to the Eunuch who had followed me, ave the beloved Sultanes, whilt I hall endeavour to do the ame to ome more expoed Peron; he took her away, and I ran to Ariania, who had oberved my behaviour, and I carried her away
eaily; reproaching the Eunuchs with their weaknes, and exhorting them to do the ame to the ret.

Mahomet and Muulman, who had een me going into the Seraglio, were ahamed to tay idle, and not follow my Example, but I was more diligent than they, and brought Ariania into a afe place. I pas'd lily towards the Gardens to convere with her in Secret, whil't the faithful Aradin carried Solimana into another place.

Ariania was almot choaked with the moak, and tho' he had the advantage of a purer Air, yet he could not uddenly recover her lot Speech; I had alo uffered much by it, and all my Cloths were poiled; but the pleaure of being with Ariania did not permit me to reflect on uch an inconiderable los. I think, my Lord, aid he to me, when he was a little recovered, that Heaven had deign'd you for the preervation of my Life; for as often as it is threatned with a danger, you hazard your own to ecure it. How fortunate hould I eteem my elf, Scanderberg, if I could acquit my elf of thoe great Obligations. Tho' you prolong but an unfortunate Life, yet
that do's not leen the dangers, to which you expoe your elf. Madam, interrupted I, had I done a thouand times more, you hould not be beholding in the leat to me, your dangers are mine own, and acting for your Security, I promote my own ret. Alas! Ariania, let not your kindnes buie it elf in taking notice of uch mall Services; but conider rather, how grievous your abence will prove to me, you know Amurat's barbarous proceedings towards our Family; my Mother tript of all her Etate and Dignity, leads an uncomfortable life, in ome corner of Albania, with her Daughters, and the illutrious Aranit, that Prince your worthy Progenitor, is forced to ubmit to a Foreign Power.

Ariania was enibly moved at my Dicoure, and her Tears tetified it. Go, my Lord, into Albania, anwered he adly to me, revenge your Royal Blood, deliver thoe great Princees, whoe only comfort you are, poes your elf of Catriot's Throne, protect Aranit, and never forget Ariania. If you were willing, Madam, replied I, I hould not fly alone. Alas! my Lord, anwered he, I could follow you without
repugnancy, was it poible for you to take me from hence; but uch an attempt can never ucceed well here at Andrinople. To prevent thoe Griefs and Alarms which abence might produce in you, I pas my word to you, I hall reit the Emperour; let him pray or threaten, 'tis all one. I embraced then Ariania's Knees, and could not refrain Tears. I wore an inviolable Contancy to her, and I bade her Adieu for the lat time, I went away according to her Command, for fear of being urprized with her.

I went to Aradin, and to Baa Acomat, and I acquainted them with what had pas'd: The fire was put out, the Sultanees hut up again, and Ariania more cloely than the ret: At lat I departed from Andrinople, recommending my Amorous concerns to Aradin; and intead of going to the place appointed to me by Amurat, I entered Albania with three hundred men, who came over to my party: There I performed thoe happy Atchievements which have amazed the whole world; I turned the Ottoman Power out of Croya, and other places of Albania, where I was proclaimed King:
the Valiant Aradin, Loyal to Our Blood, and concerned for his dear Ariania, did for me all that I could expect from an affectionate Father. Vranus, Illutrious both for his Birth and Merit, tuck very cloe to me, I did not enjoy the pleaure of eeing my Mother again, who was dead for grief, he had given three Illutrious Husbands to three of my Siters, and Amia only was not marry'd.

Amurat fell into a rage, as oon as he heard my advantages, and aw himelf deprived in few days of a great number of fine Provinces. He ent a prodigious Army to regain them. But firt I defeated Sebaia, and afterwards Alibeg, who commanded fourty thouand Men. After this, I won an immortal Fame in Varna's Battel: Amurat wrote to me like a Mater, and I anwer'd him like a King, who depied him. In one word, without mentioning all other paages, Amurat came in peron, followed by a numberles Army, after I had defeated Mutapha his Baa.

I could never learn ince Ariania's condition, tho' I have done all my endeavours to be intructed by thoe Turks, who are faln into our hands, becaue
they know but little what Amurat does. I have been told only, that he is loved till, that Muulman is digraced, and abent, and that Mahomet does not well agree with his Father. You know, Thopia, what has pat ince we aw Amurat about Croya, and by my lat cruel adventure you may judge of my grief.

Here the King of Albania made an end of his Dicoure, and ighed after uch a manner, that Thopia, who really loved him, could not but pity him. Scanderberg was not concerned alone for Ariania's misfortunes. Aranit, her loving Father, had been extreamly enible of her Captivity, and coming to ee Scanderberg, he heard the caue of his extraordinary adnes. We mut all die, my Lord, aid he to Ariania's Father; but before we die, let us render our Arms formidable to Amurat, let us return on him that terrour he trikes into our hearts, and let whole Torrents of Turkih blood wah off the Crime committed againt the innocent Ariania.

Scanderberg was not able to go on. Thopia informed Prince Aranit, what was the reaon of his cruel rage, he was amazed at it, but could not believe what he feared was true. My Lord,
aid he to the King, Amurat's Note •• a ign of his rage; but it is likely, an Command hath not been executed: And I cannot imagine, Heavens Jutice could permit uch a Sacrifice. If Ariania is dead, we hall have time enough to be wail her los; in the mean time, let us inform our elves about her Detiny Aranit's Contancy, who could not be accued of loving coldly the mot amiable Daughter in the World, pacified i • little Scanderberg. Well, aid he, let us get ome intructions about that, but let it be with our Arms, and all out Forces. If our Subjects deire to ee a glorious Battel, let them come to this. Go, Thopia, aid he to the young Prince, encourage the Army to do its duty, carry there mine Orders, and the News of my Dipleaure: do not leen to them the height of my grief: Animate the Captains and Souldiers, and help me to go in a Conquet.

Thopia obey'd the King's Orders, and within a hort time Scanderberg's Apartment was filled with Perons of Quality, who were ready to ignalize their Valour, eeing him reolved to attack the Turks in their Retrenchments in what time and poture oever. Thopia's,
Commotion did not differ much from that of Scanderberg. And Aranit in pight of Age hew'd all the vigour deired in a man of younger years. The famous Ducagins, the renowned Spani, Dumani, Zacharia, Cernoniqui, and many others appeared at the head of their Albanian Forces: The orders having been given every where, the invincible Scanderberg appeared at the head of his Army wearing black Feathers; there was to be een uch a mixture of grief and pride in his Eyes, that his ight would move ome to pity, and trike terror into Others. Having cat his looks upon his Forces, and having oberved the contancy, which appeared in the leat of his Souldiers, Ariania, aid he, ighing, your precious blood will be expiated by that of your barbarous murthers. After that he pake thus to them.

Generous Princes, Valliant Captains, brave Souldiers, Loyal Subjects of Epirus, and Albania; he that peaks to you, is going to lead you againt an Enemy, who might affright another Nation, and truts your noble Courage with his Glory and Revenge. Ariania was born amongt you, you know her illutrious Family; and Aranit's
actions have made him famous all the World over: you are to fight to day for the innocent blood of that illutrious, but unfortunate Princes; let the Daughters Condition, the Fathers Sorrow, and the Lover's Dipair, inpire you with an extraordinary Bravery. You want no examples, but had you need of any, Scanderberg may hew you ome, worthy to be follow'd, come, Freinds, let us vanquih or dye for Ariania. When he had aid thee words, he let his Hore go, and the ret of that mighty Body followed his motions.

The Scouts of the Sultan's Camp oon dicovered Scanderberg's March, and brought word to Amurat. He was well experienced in Warlike Matters, and knew well what he ought to do, Orcan brought his orders to the ret of his Officers. Every one went where his preence was required, and Sultan Mahomet, hating Scanderberg, and deiring to keep in his Fathers favour, appeared the readiet, and the willinget to fight. Aconot, the King of Albania's generous Friend, did not go there to fight againt him. There was as many Souldiers left in the Camp, as were neceary to ecure it, and all the other
Forces, which were to encounter Scanderberg went out.
As oon as he perceived their Standard, he ent forth a Cry, which was anwered by all his Men; and with a threatning Look, and naked Sword, he went to meet the Enemy.

The Turks, who had een him vanquih o often, trembled at his firt ight. Amurat himelf, notwithtanding all his Pride and Cruelty, was much concerned. Mahomet, jealous of Scanderberg's Glory, and of the other advantages he had above him, apired to an immortal Fame by killing him. And Orcan, deiring to keep to himelf the Sultan's favour, wihed nothing o much as to acrifice that Illutrious Victim to his Mater's reentment.

p.U:
pared no body in his firt tranport; even Amurat, whoe Dignity he had repected till then, had felt himelf the trength of his Arm, had he not been encompas'd by a crowd of Turks.
