How formidable is a valiant Man, when Love and Revenge encourage him to fight! What abundance of Blood was pilt in few moments! What vat number of Turks did the King of Albania kill? And how many
fine Exploits were that day, performed by his Friends? Aranit was not at all enible of his old Age; and the young Thopia let the Ottomans know there was more than one Hero in Albania.

div.p: They had already defeated Amurat's Van-guard, took his Standards, made Prioners many of his Captains, and Victory did already begin to incline on Scanderberg's ide, when Night put an end to their Fighting, tho' the Quarrel was not fully decided. Scanderberg would have purued the Turks, but the Darknes became o thick he was fain to tay till to Morrow.

After the Lights had been kindled, as Scanderberg was going to enjoy a little ret, there was a kind of Prodigy een; his Semitar had cleaved o fat to his hand in the heat of the Fight, that it could not be pluck'd off but with extraordinary pains: This was taken for an aured ign of his Strength and Valour.

His firt care was to enquire about Aranit, who was no more to be een, he was ought for to no purpoe; and Scanderberg feared either he was dead or taken: He was thinking upon this when he perceived Acomat coming,
who to ee him, had revolted in the dead of the Night to his Party.

Scanderberg embraced him with all demontations of joy; and the generous Turk received his Carees with all orts of repect. My dear Acomat, aid the amorous Scanderberg to him, do you come to confirm Ariania's death, or to reproach me with my weaknes. No, my Lord, replyed Acomat, I do not bring you o ad news. Ariania is till alive in the Sultan's Camp. You have a mind, aid the King of Albania, to deceive my grief. I have een Amurat's Command, replyed Acomat; and then he hew'd him the Paper found upon Aradin, whoe unfortunate Fate he acquainted him with. I took that faithful Eunuch to be with you, my Lord, and he left Amurat's Camp, only to pas into yours. But without doubt, Muelman, who hides himelf not far from hence, had kill'd him. As for Ariania, he is alive, and you may rely upon my word for that.

One cannot expres how much then was Scanderberg's joy. Aranit was ought after; but ome Souldiers aid, they thought he had been made Prioner,
having een him venture too far among the Turks.

They took that night the mot convenient meaures for their afety, tho' it was not likely that Amurat, half vanquihed, would come again to a Battel; there were Sentinels plac'd every where, and the news of Ariania's Life were brought to Croya. Scanderberg enjoy'd more ret that night than uually; at break of Day they viited all the Corps, but could never find Aranit's.

Scanderberg was reolved to fulfill his Victory, and to free Ariania and her Father from his Enemies. Acomat aured him Amurat expected a coniderable uccour. Scanderberg was but little alarm'd with this; and the hope of delivering Ariania prevail'd more upon his mind than any other conideration.

Aranit's Captivity was oon confirmed; and there were news brought to Scanderberg's Camp that Amurat had more rejoyced at it than at the gaining of everal Battels, having now in his power what to affright Ariania with: That fair Princes had uffered a thouand orrows ince Scanderberg's departure; and the Emperour's violent deires could not have been reited but by an extraordinary
Virtue, uch as hers: But all her pas'd ufferings were but light, compar'd with her affliction for her Father's Captivity. Amurat ent for him; and Aranit, who had not een Acomat, and was not acquainted with Ariania's condition, look'd extreamly ad. Thou art vanquih'd and ubdu'd to our Power, aid the Sultan to him, and notwithtanding all the pride of thy Family, thou mut toop before us. Thou needs not thank Fortune, reply'd Aranit, which hath delivered into thy hands an unfortunate Victim, and which longs to be acrificed: So many great Men as till remain in our Party, under Scanderberg's Conduct will find thee work enough. Tho' they have urpried us, replyed Amurat, yet thou may't judge by thy preent condition of the inconiderablenes of their advantages; and that I have no great reaon to fear them. But that is not the thing now: I will propoe unto thee a afe way to free thy elf. Thou cant not propoe any, aid Aranit, but what is hameful; and he that had murdered Ariania—hold, interrupted Amurat, and do not accue me of a crime I was never guilty
of Ariania lives, but till o cruel, that I want thy aitance to change her mind; thou hall ee her, but thou mut ue this liberty for my ervice: I love her, I adore her, but the Ungrateful depies my flame with a cruel obtinacy. Reflect, Aranit, how hameful it is for uch a Man as I to igh, and uffer to no purpoe, nor any take care of my reentments.

Aranit was no fit confident for Amurat: Scanderberg, his King and his Friend was in love with Ariania, and was belov'd by her: Thee being thus, he was not capable of a bae compliance: Thou knowet, aid he, Chritians are eldom fearful, and that they eldom act againt their Parole or Duty; how dear oever Ariania may be to me, I would ooner ee her dead than to bring her to grant thee thy requet. Hearing this dicoure, which could be o eaily undertood, Amurat grew mad againt Aranit: Tarry my Prioner, ince thou depiet my Proffers, aid he to him; all Scanderberg's Power hall not be able to deliver thee, and thou hall quickly feel what detiny I prepare for thee. Then he ent him back into a private Tent, and commanded
he hould be kept cloely.

Having found the Father o reolute, he went to try whether the Daughter would prove alo inflexible: Therefore he went to Ariania, who knew not what had pas'd; Cruel Ariania, aid he to her, I protrate my elf to your feet, for the lat time of my life, to deire ome mall favour from you, which I promie to retaliate, by releaing Aranit your Father, who is now my Prioner. Heavens! cry'd Ariania, is this the lat Affliction you prepared againt me? And do you forake the jut party, to cat me till into new Troubles? Alas! dear Father, Why did not my Death prevent your Misfortune? You may dipoe of his Detiny, reply'd Amurat, and it depends wholly upon your Behaviour. Reflect earnetly upon this, do not depie mine Anger; and tho you need not fear the los of your Death, yet fear that of Auranit's. Tyrant, reply'd the Princes full of orrow and indignation, what hath my Father done againt thee? Is this the ue thou oughtet to make of what Power the chance of War hath given thee over him? Alas! he is falln into this danger only to deliver me: Endeavour then
on your ide his Deliverance, reply'd Amurat, ince I am reolv'd to be cruel except you favour me; either you mut love, or ee Aranit dye. Is this thy way of gaining love, reply'd the fair Ariania? is Cruelty uch a pleaing Charm, and mut we offend the Peron by whom we deire to be loved? Give ome occaion to my Heart to be grateful, boat ooner of thy Services than thy Rage, to the end thou may't upbraid me with ome reaon. You have taken o little notice of my Sufferings, reply'd the Sultan, that I intend to follow no more that coure. If you are till the ame, I will not warrant you of my Fury; but if you change, you may expect any thing from me, and dipoe at your pleaure, of my Soul and Empire: Well, anwered Ariania, let me ee my Father. Tho' I ought to refue this Favour, to a peron who never granted me any; yet interrupted Amurat, I give you leave to ee him, but do not forget when you embrace him, that his Life depends upon this interview: Take together uch Reolutions as may be agreeable with my Deigns. The Sultan went away without peaking any more, and ordered Ariania hould
be brought to Aranit's Tent, not far from her's.

Four Years abence had made but an advantagious alteration in the Princes: And Aranit who knew well her Suffering, wondred to find her o fair. Preently he embraced her Fathers Knees, and weeped there abundantly: He embraced her a thouand times, and took her up very lovingly. After he had atisfied the firt motions of Nature, I ee you again at lat, aid he, dear Ariania, after I have o long bewailed your los, and lived in a orrow proportioned to the caue thereof. If I have taken any care of my days, it was only to the end they might be erviceable to you. I have een the Emperour of the Turks; I have heard, but I find not my elf dipos'd to do what he deir'd.—Forgive me, my Lord, if I interrupt you to praie your Contancy, it is worthy of your elf; but hall I ee you dye, rather than give my elf to Amurat? And ought I not to acrifice the Peace of my Life to the afety of yours? What Ariania, reply'd Aranit, could you reolve your elf to be the Mitres of a Turkih Prince? How orrowful would this ign of your love prove to me, and by preerving my
life, how intollerable would you render it? I can loe it a thouand ways without glory; and you ought not to preerve it by o bae means, ince hould I conent to it, I cannot but loe my good Fame amongt all honet Men. In a word, Ariania, forake ooner both my Life and yours, if there is any need. I tremble giving you this advice, but I hould bluh hould I do otherwie. Remember what you owe to the King of Albania, to that Prince who before he knew you, had erved you with o much repect. Alas! My Lord, I have forgotten neither his Valour, nor his Services. Conider to what dreadful pas I am brought: Shall my love upbraid for ever my evere Vertue, by reaon I have not aved your life when I could do it? And if I grant Amurat's deire, will not the whole World look upon me as upon a Princes perfidious, both to Heaven and Scanderberg? Alas! my Lord, what hall I do? That which I have advied to, anwered the contant Aranit: But then I hall ee you dye, aid the Princes; no matter for that, reply'd Aranit, I hall dye without hame: Then both began to weep in a ad manner. The Eunuch's Witnees of this orrowful
Converation, put an end to it, and Ariania was like to dye, taking her lat leave from her Father: Did I ee you only, my Lord, to bid you an eternal farewell, cry'd the deolate Princes. Cruel Amurat, let me dye with Aranit: Moderate your Grief, reply'd the Prince, oftly: We are not o far from Scanderberg, you know what his Valour can do; go away my dear Ariania, and never depair as long as he lives.

'Tis impoible to expres Amurat's Rage, when he heard in what manner the Father and Daughter had poke one to another: Am I Soveraign only, aid he, to be hector'd by my Enemies? And hall I always ee my Power inulted over? Let them dye ooner; and tho' I cannot quench a Flame which I abhor, let my Reaon at leat condemn to an everlating Grief the peron that caues it; let the World ee what Revenge I will take of a Captive, who does but increae Ariania's hatred againt me: Let him dye, I don't quetion but Scanderberg, whom my Arms hall punih as a Fugitive Rebel, will reent this los. Let Ariania have a jut reaon to complain of me; heretofore he had only been the witnes of my weaknes, but now
he hall ee me pill her own Blood.

As oon as he had reolved this, he thought upon the means of bringing it to execution: He choe his Camp to be the Stage where that Tragedy was to be acted. The mot uual kind of Death among the Turks is Strangling; but uch Executions are frequently very private: That would not erve the Sultan's turn, who intended to hew publickly his Cruelty, that Ariania might be the witnes thereof.

The next day all things were prepared for Aranit's death; a Scaffold was erected in the middle of the Camp, which was encompaed by the Janiary's, and other Souldiers of the Guard; Amurat took a convenient place to ee his Orders executed, and the deolate Ariania was brought near him. The Sultan kept always his dreadful looks upon her, but he turned hers towards Heaven to implore its Aitance.

A trange Spectacle was offer'd to their ight. Aranit appeared in uch a mierable condition, that it could not but hake his Daughter's Contancy: He was loaded with huge Chains, had his hands tyed, and his head uncovered, but he eemed neither cat down nor affrighted
at this barbarous uage: He walk't with a edate countenance, as depiing his Enemies; but when he aw Ariania o frighted, almot drowned in her Tears, and almot dead for Grief, he grew pale, and pityed the deplorable condition of that lovely Princes, who had always been the dearet Object of his Hopes and Love; he wept, but his great courage could not allow of uch Tears, and preently he wiped them off. He was no more dicountenanced then, than if he had been at the head of his Army; and recovering his former Tranquillity, he lifted up his Voice that he might be heard by the Sultan, the Princes, and the ret of the Aitance. Ariania, aid he to her, do not think this eems either cruel or hameful to me; I find therein both glory and pleaure, ince you ee there an Example of which you can make ome ue: Hide thoe Tears from me, which argue your weaknes: You are my Daughter, but remember alo that you are a Princes, that rank where Heaven has et you, requires both contancy and a great reolution; you will ee me no more, 'tis true, but let this conideration comfort you, That no bae Action will blemih the Glory
of my Life; come to your elf, dear Ariania, live for Scanderberg's ake; nay, dye for him, if there is need, as I am confident he would do for you. As for the Emperour of the Turks, aid he, turning himelf towards Amurat, a Prince born from o many Heroe's, from whom thou degenerates o much, and whoe Cruelty thou only imitatet; learn from my Death to depie Life. Yeterday I was with the valiant Scanderberg, whoe very preence diipates Fear and Terrour, and behold now I am ubmitted to a Tyrant who trembles at the leat thing.

Let him dye and perih, cry'd out the Emperour, and let him be punihed for his pride. Then the Executioners went about to obey his Orders, and the fair Ariania falling into a Swound, was carryed to the Tent where he had always been.

But whilt they were preparing to execute Aranit, many repeated out-cry's of the farthet Sentinels, ignify'd Scanderberg's coming, who had enjoyed no ret ince Aranit's Captivity: His Forces brought again to fight, did march with a warlike Contancy, which truck terror into the firt that aw them. Amurat's
Camp was oon in a great fright; he was reolved to haten Aranit's Execution; but Orcan, who could prevail the bet upon his mind, got it to be upended, judging it would be convenient to keep him alive: He was therefore brought back again, and Amurat put on his Arms, having till coniderable Forces left, which were oon in a poture of Defence.

Scanderberg broke like Thunder through whole Squadrons; Amurat was mightily afraid of his rencounter, and therefore went another way, leaving Orcan to deal with Scanderberg: The valiant Thopia attacked the Sultan, and let him know the King of Albania was well econded. The Turks turned back every where, confuion and horrour had eized them; Amurat eeing there was no hope of the Victory left him, ran to Ariania's Tent with a barbarous intent, but could not find her there; and was trangely amazed when he heard, that Muelman whom he took to be far from thence, had toln her away: Beides this Grif, he was put to a hameful flight; Scanderberg remained the only Mater of the Field and Bagage; he aw Aranit, but could not find Ariania. Who
can expres his Sorrow, when he aw all his Attempts fruitles, and o much Blood pilt to no purpoe, and when he heard in whoe hands he had faln? He took this at firt for a trick of the Sultan, who being defeated, hided Ariania's condition: Conidering this, he was reolved to root out his Souldiers before they had time to breath, but ome Turkih Prioners told him for certain, that Muelman had gotten her away.

Scanderberg could not but think, that Muelman had no deign to bring her into Amurat's Territories, or tarry in Albania; he feared all things; and the knowledge he had of Muelman's temper, did but increae his dreadful trouble: To comfort himelf, he embraced Aranit, who acquainted him with his pat Dangers. After he had ettled his Camp, and left the ditribution of the Pillage to the greedy Souldiers, every one endeavoured to divert his Sorrow. Thopia was more buie in it than any: You were never acquainted with Love, aid the Prince of Albania to Thopia, and therefore you cannot imagine my Sorrow; Thopia bluhed at this reproach, which he was o far from deerving, ince
no heart was more addicted to that Paion than his. I am more acquainted with Love than you think, my Lord, reply'd he; and becaue I know its effects, I pity you more than any. My Lord, reply'd ranus, whoe only deire was to divert the King from thoe ad thoughts, to convince the King of the truth of what you ay; pray let him hear your love Adventures. I hall hear them, aid the King to Thopia with pleaure and attention, howoever prepoeed I may be; and if you are not a fortunate Lover, my own Experience will teach me to commierate you. My Lord, anwered Thopia, both my Love and Fortune wholly depend upon your pleaure, and the account which I am to give you by your Command, will make you more enible of that Truth.

div.head: The Hitory of THOPIA.
div.p:
WAS Love a voluntary Paion, my Lord, and could we rule the motions of our Hearts according to the advices of Reaon, we hould never pich upon any choice without firt conulting her. Firt of all, I mut needs tell you, my Lord, that I love the Princes Aa,
and that all my repect could never top my paion. I beg humbly your Pardon.—I do forgive you with all my heart, reply'd the King, and I cannot but admire my Siter's Happines, to poes uch a Noble Heart. Thopia then fell upon his Knees, but being taken up by Scanderberg, he went on after this manner.

I hell'd a coniderable rank in King Catriot's Court, upon my Fathers account; and after you had been ent to Amurat, I was look't upon as the chiefet of the Princes of Albania. I was urnamed Carlomus, which ignifies in the Sclavonian Tongue happy, either becaue I was very aimable in mine Infancy, or becaue I was prung from the Noble Blood of Charlemayne.

The King who could ee you no more, never look't upon me without ighing, and without complaining of that cruel Law, which deprived him of your preence. The Princees Angelina, Zella, and lacia, your Siters, comforted the Queen Vorana, being already come to years of reaon, ince they were oon after marry'd to three illutrious Husbands: But the young Amia was till in her firt Infancy, o fair and charming,
that one could not look upon her without loving and admiring her. I fell in love with her as oon as I was enible of any Reaon, and our free Converation did but increae my Paion.

The Prince Muachius my Father, who had had me in his old Age, when he had no hopes of any Son, was o overioyed with the advantage of having a •• on, that all the care he took, was a
••• t mine Education.

All Amia's Actions eemed charming to me, and I wiht mine had not dipleas'd her: I was a long while before I could acquaint her with my Paion, and whatoever my complaiance towards her might be, he was to young to gues the meaning of it.

As for me, a little more Age and Experience had taught me to ditinguih Love from Friendhip; and Time acquainted the Princes, that one doe's not igh without Love: In my younger Age I had hewn but a quiet joy at her ight, but as oon as I came to my ixteenth year, he oberved I was melancholly and perplexed.

She was ued to go very often with her Governants, to divert her elf a fihing in the great Pond, which was in
the middle of the Palace of Croya; I follow'd her there one day, and whilt her waiting Women were talking at ome ditance from us, I aw her longer than an hour apply only her elf to that Exercie: She was o fair, that I look'd upon her with an extraordinary attention, and in that pleaing occupation, I ighed o loud, that Amia who could catch nothing, and was vexed at it, turned angrily her head towards me; Thopia, aid he to me, I think you affright the Fihes, and the noie of your Sighs poils all my port. Alas! Madam, reply'd I, how can they hear what you do not hearken to. 'Tis poible enough, reply'd he, that I hear you without hearkning to you: If you hear my Sighs, Madam, aid I, I am certain you do not undertand the meaning of them, and I hould be too happy were you acquainted with that Secret. The Princes left her Fihing to look upon me more earnetly; and cating one obliging look upon me, I eteem you o far as to pity you for your misfortunes, aid he, and to rejoyce at your advantages: And I am willing to know that Secret, if you think I may erve you therein. Madam, reply'd I, I will
then impart it to your kindnes, and tell you, that you are the caue of my ufferings. I the caue of your ufferings, cry'd the young Princes, with a kind of amazement, mixed with fear, Alas! Thopia, how can that be, ince I bear you o good a will? I do not tell you, Madam, added I, that they are caued by your will. I uffer, tho' you do not intend to make me uffer. You puzzle me trangely, replyed Amia, and I mut confes my Wit is not piercing enough, to apprehend that Mytery. I perceive, Madam, added I, trembling, that my mouth mut be my heart's interpreter. I love you, and thoe ighs which trouble your innocent port, proceeds only from that extraordinary love you have inpir'd me with; this paion is almot as old as I, and I was enible of it, before I did know my elf. Alas! Thopia, replyed the Princes with a charming innocence, do not talk to me about Love, it has been repreented always to me, after uch a manner, that I will hun it like a Monter, and if you deire I hould ee you, you mut rid your elf of it. 'Tis impoible, Madam, reply'd I, I hould part with it, and I perceive, I am its lave for the ret of my life. But, Madam,
do you think, a Paion, which you inpire me with, can be any thing frightful? that Love which hath been drawn to you, was no uch Love as mine, nor the effect of divine Amia's Charms. If there is any horror to be found therein, it concerns me alone, and it proceeds from the fear of dipleaing you. But, Thopia, replyed the Princes, what do you deire from me? Your pity, Madam, added I, and a Confeion from your mouth, that you accept of my Services with ome joy. I profes to you, anwered the Princes, that I do not apprehend half of what you ay, and that I want many Leons to undertand this matter; did your heart tutor you o well, added I, as mine does me, you would be oon as great a Scholar in it as I, I promie you replyed he miling, to impart to you all that it hall teach me, in the mean time uppres your ighs, and help me to conquer the ill luck I have to day.
I was well pleaed with this converation, and I did what ever I could to atisfie Amia. At lat the enchantment ended, and we caught fihes a pace, o that we entered into the Palace very well contented.

Since that day, the Princes made ome Reflections, which opened her eyes. She had always looked upon me, as upon a young Prince, with whom he was allowed to live familiar, but after that my dicoure, my actions, and her own reaon had acquainted her, that I was in love with her, and when he conidered the conequences which would follow the Courthip of a declared Lover, he took a evere Countenance, and tho' he never hew'd any hatred againt me, yet I could not perceive in her that innocent kindnes, which till then had flatter'd my hopes.

I was oon enible of this Change, which is imputed to indifferency; ome time pas'd before I could complain, but my grief prevailing upon my patience, at lat I poke thus to the Princes. Madam, aid I to her, you have taught me to love, but I am afraid, I have taught you to hate, and except your kindnes take my part, I fear let your rigour deprives me of the Liberty of eeing you. Are thee the leons you have learnt from your heart, and did you conult it only to render it mine Enemy? You will never be able to teach me to hate; but, My Lord, replyed he, I
don't care you hould teach me to love; but uppoe I am now a little more reerved, ought you to wonder at it? 'Tis enough, Thopia, aid he, cating an obliging look upon me, that there is no other difference between what I was, and what I am. I know not whether this Kindnes is a Leon from my heart, but as long as it hall not inpire me with any thing inconitent with my Duty, you need not fear I hould take any reolutions contrary to your interet. I found o much reaon in this dicoure, that it increaed both my Love and Repect. It would be both ungrateful and rude in me, aid I, to ask any more, ince only my ervices, and modety ought to peak for me.

p.U: eemed pleaed with this anwer, but whilt I was abandoning entirely my elf to that paion, and he look'd upon me, as a man who was worthy to erve her, Fate prepared it elf to cros us.

div.p:
Catriot, who had married the Princees his daughters with ome Albanian Princes, could hardly have found a Family more worthy of his Alliance than ours. The Queen, who loved more tenderly Amia than the others, fearing
let ome Reaon of State hould remove her into a Forreign Country, liked my paion well enough; but the King, who had ome different deigns, took meaures quite oppoite to hers.

Among thoe that were of ome note at Croya, Balé, a Prince as well as I, had become Catriot's Favourite, he was no man of great Vices, nor of an extraordinary Virtue, and the only thing that got him in favour, was his affected complyance. He was ten years older than I, and was not handome to pleae the Eyes of a nice Princes. Yet Catriot had choen him for Amia's Huband, and had thought that his Sons being abent, Epirus and Albania could not have a better Protector.

Some Broils then call'd us to the War, I was none of the unwillinget to go, acrificing my Paion to Glory, and to the deire of deerving Amia. I did not part from her without Sorrow, and I believe he was alo enible of my departure. Balé commanded our Army, and becaue there were but few Frontiere-places revolted, it was not very Numerous. I did not then look upon him as my Rival, yet I had no love for him; he had, may be, no greater
hare in the Victories we got, than I, and the others that erved, but he was rewarded a great deal better. Arriving to Croya, I found the Princes Amia afflicted, for Ariania's los, whom a Caravanne of Turks had toln away in a Voyage, which her Father had impoed upon her without any neceity.

About that time, My Lord, the whole world pake of you with admiration, and your Conquets, both in Aia and Africa, amazed the mot experienced Souldiers. Catriot had then good reaon to igh, eeing that what Services you did for an Infidel, might have proved o ueful for Chritendom. The Princes wihed your return, and when I would commend you in her preence, Pity that Illutrious Brother, would he ay, that his valour hould be engaged to erve a man of a barbarous extraction, and who knows little what belongs to gratitude, and friendhip. Pity me at the ame time for loving him as much as I do, and for having no hopes to ee him again.
But, My Lord, 'tis time to relate to you my Sorrows; the King your Father, who thought he was mightily beholding to Balé, prepared to do any thing for him.

This formidable Rival for reaon of Catriot's protection, began to court the Princes in uch a manner, that I was deprived of the liberty I had before. As oon as I aw he had declared himelf, I was enible of my misfortune, and tho' he was a King's Favourite, yet I defired my Father to do omething for my love. He loved me too tenderly to deny me any thing I asked, and without objecting to me all that I ought to fear, he did partly what I deired.

I went to expect with the Princes the event of my Father's deign. I ound her orrowful, and melancholy. You are afflicted, Madam, aid I to her, and that trouble which appears in your eyes ignifies as much. Yes, Prince, replyed he, with a ad Countenance, I am cruelly perplexed. Can I without offending you, ask you the Caue thereof, replyed I? You will know it too oon, and if you are a little concerned for me, what will you ay, when you hear I am near to marry Balé? This dicoure, like a thunder, truck me almot dead, and I was o little prepared for it, that this urprie topt my blood, and one could ee upon my Face, the igns of a real depair. The Princes
was moved at it. Alas! Thopia, aid he, looking adly upon me, how dear am I like to pay for my Obedience to my Fathers Commands? Madam, aid I, are you then reolved to marry Balé, and by a Scruple of Virtue will you ooner renounce your own happines, than reit Catriot's will? Would you have me, replyed he, incur his indignation by a rebellious reitance? Tho' you might love me the better for it, yet I am ure you would eteem me the les, and you know your elf well enough, that a Daughter of my rank, cannot dipoe of her own Fate. I know, I adore you, Madam, aid I, and I hall dye for grief, if Balé injoy a Fortune he has never deerved. What great advantages above me can that Fortunate Rival boat of? I am certain, I give him none, interrupted Amia, and were you only to trive with my inclination, you would oon be a Conqueror. But, Thopia, you know Catriot is my Father, and what power he has over me. What hall I do, replyed I, if you marry Balé, you hall ee me no more, or at mot? You hall ee me only in publick places, replyed the Princes. And if I live, I hall live the mot unfortunate
peron in the World. Can you, Madam, give your elf to him, replyed I, omewhat angry? Yes, without doubt, interrupted Amia, and I ee nothing can dipene me from that Duty, if Catriot requires it of me. Cruel Princes, aid I, you know well enough I cannot live after that; mut I alo adore your Fortunate Husband, as I do every thing that belongs to you? Did you know my hearts Condition, replyed he, you would not be o paionate, and you would ooner endeavour to comfort it. My trouble does not proceed from any affectation. However you are more fortunate then I, ince you are not forced to give your elf to one you hate, and ince you may igh without crime. In my preent confuion, I know not, aid I, what to ay, nor what to think. All things eem guilty to me, and I cannot but accue my elf, believing heaven would never punih me undeervedly. After that I asked the Princes, how he came to know Balé's good Fortune? And he told me, that after he had often poke to her about his love, but in vain, the King at lat had declared himelf for him, notwithtanding the Queen's averion to it,
and that he had commanded the Princes to look upon Balé as upon a Prince whom he deigned for her future Husband.

I perceived then that all my Father's endeavours would prove fruitles, and I was grievouly afflicted at this. Amia eemed alo very enible of my orrow, and her kindnes did but give me a greater ene of my los.

Againt my cutom I was glad to leave her, intending to go to the Queen, who had always been kind to me, to implore her aitance. I was told he was in the Gardens, therefore going that way, I met my Father, whoe melancholy Countenance did but increae my trouble: He confirm'd unto me the King's reolution in Bale's behalf, and exhorted me to take patiently a mifortune which could not be helpt. In the ame minute I aw my Rival appear, follow'd by many Courtiers, drawn there by his fair hopes; my colour chang'd, and my Father enible of my violent commotion, forbad me to enter into any converation with Balé: what could I have promied him, ince I was matered by a Paion I could no longer bridle? It was well I did not attack
my Rival in his preence; but as oon as he diappear'd I abandoned my elf to Wrath and Jealouie. I found Balé in the Garden where I was looking for the Queen. Could I peak one word with you, aid I? Yes, replyed he, without any apparent amazement. I know, aid I, that you are deign'd to poes the only thing that may render you the mot glorious Man in the World: But you don't know, it may be, that I igh for the Princes Amia thee many years ago, and that you mut deprive me of my life ooner than obtain her. I did not think, replyed Balé, in a cornful manner, which vexed me to the very heart, that the deigns of a great King were to be cros'd thus. For my part, I, who know how I am to obey, ought to take the greatet care to perform my duty. Do not conclude from hence, that I don't care to fight with you; you hall have that atisfaction: But, Thopia, you will not take it ill if I defer it till Marriage hath given me a full poeion of Amia.

Having thus poke to me, he left me cornfully; and I was o much cat down at thoe words, that I could not attack him at preent. The Place was
a Sacred Place, and I was fain to curb my Paions. As they were acting within me with the greatet violence, the Queen came, and I went to her in a trouble which he eaily took notice of. That generous Princes cat a ad look upon me; and leaving her Gentleman-Uher to give me her hand, he did not ask the reaon of my orrow, which he eaily gueed, but let me know how afflicted he was at the King's prepoeion in Balé's behalf, auring me, that if he had had the dipoal of my good Fortune, he had not deferred it a moment. I wih, aid he, I could procure your atisfaction with the los of my own Blood; but we have a Mater obtinate in his reolutions, and who will be obeyed. I have trove againt them as much as I could, but all to no purpoe, and I cannot but condole with you. The palenes and the depair that appeared upon my face at the hearing of thee words cat the Queen into a great fright. Madam, aid I to her, my misfortunes are o great that 'tis like they will alo prove fatal to Balé, and all the repect I owe to the King's order can never prevent my reentment. Catriot came afterwards, follow'd by
the Princes, and I retir'd in that ad condition.

Amia, who aw me retire, eaily perceiv'd my trouble, ince I eemed to hun her preence. I pent that night in the greatet trouble imaginable. I had a thouand everal Projects in my Head; at lat I reolved to render Amia's poeion impoible for Balé. I had een him in everal occaions, but I never had the leat fear his arms hould triumph over me as his favour did: In fine, I roe up at the break of day, and went to tarry for him near the Palace where he was ued to go every Morning. Balé, aid I, as oon as I aw him, we mut fight for Amia, and you will never be happy before you have killed me. Then I drew my Sword, my Rival was forced to do the ame, and we fought with equal courage and advantage; we wounded one another in everal places; and tho' they endeavour'd to part us, yet our fight lated o long, that it exhauted the greatet part of our trength. Balé at lat fell at my feet; and tho' I tood up till, yet I was in a ad condition; a crowd of people coming then carried us both away.

The King hewed uch a great reentment to my Father, who endeavour'd to jutifie me, that his great grief cat him into a Fever, which brought him to the Grave. I durt not appear, and this increas'd my depair. The Queen and Princes ent me word how much concerned they were for me: But nothing could atisfie Catriot but my death, hould Balé live no longer; his wounds were more coniderable than mine; I was curld in a hort time, notwithtanding my grief, but all the care they took of him could not prevent his death.

Then, my Lord, I could no longer tarry in Croya, or in any other place of Albania; Catriot had no regard for my Love, nor Services, nor Birth, and granting ome tears to Balé's death, he fully reolved my own. The Princes, whom he upected to favour me, felt his everity; even the Queen her elf underwent his reproaches.

I thought it very hard to hide my elf for a glorious action, and I had fallen into a depair, if the Princes, who could obtain any thing from me, and who knew well I was not out of Croya, where I was carefully ought after, and who feared Catriot's reentment, had
not precrib'd a Law which I could not reit. I receiv'd her orders in a Letter written with her own hand, which was delivered to me with a great deal of circumpection.

body.head: The Princes Amia to Thopia.
body.p: AS one cannot reaonably expect any ret from violent actions, o we might have been happier had you not been o paionate. If I have any power over you, and if you put any trut in me, avoid for a while the King's dipleaure: The Queen wihes it, and I beg it of you. Abent your elf, Thopia; I fear the los of your life; this Leon proceeds from my heart: Remember our former converations, and believe for your own comfort, that now it is you may be as good a Scholar as yours.

div.p: Tho' abence eemed to me a more cruel pain than any that Catriot's wrath could prepare, yet I reolved to obey the Princes, and to acquaint her with it, I ent her this anwer.

body.head: Thopia to the Princes Amia.
body.p: THe greatet demontration both of Love and Repect that I can give you, is, to go out of Croya and Albania, where I leave you likely for ever. I do not repine at my ufferings, ince your pleaure will have it o. I hall depart, Madam; but let me beg that protection from your heart, without which I I hould never be able to endure the pains of abence. Adieu, I may dye without eeing you, but never without adoring your charms.

div.p:
I wihed I could have taken my leave of Amia, but the then preent Juncture of Affairs would not allow of a private interview. I parted from Croya with a ound body, but a heart full of grief. I took with me ome of my faithful Servants, abandoning whatever my Father had left me. There was then no War in any place of Europe, and having no certain Deign, I was led at lat by my profound Melancholy into a part of Greece; as I was thinking upon a larger Journey, I heard of Catriot's death. How unjut oever he
had been againt me, I was afflicted at the News; I had returned to Croya, if Amurat's Tyranny, who had poes'd himelf of all Albania, had not put an invincible top to my Deigns. The Queen and Amia were made Captives, and having no Forces to defend, I went every where to make ome interet for them, and made at lat that Party, which I brought to you after the Queen's Death, which oppreed me almot with grief, entirely honouring her, and knowing how enible Amia would be of this Misfortune.

In fine, my Lord, I was Witnes of your immortal Actions; I aw Amia again, whom I found the ame, and who told me, that my happines wholly depended upon your pleaure. This is that Hitory, my Lord, you deired to know, you are both my King and Mater, but beides you are the Sovereign Umpire of my Felicity.
Scanderberg embraced Thopia as oon as he had made an end of his Relation, and aured him, that he might poes Amia when he pleaed, and that nothing would be o acceptable to him as his Union.

But tho' Scanderberg's violent paion had been diverted for a while by Thopia's Relation, yet it oon recovered its former trength, the orrowful Aranit was much concerned, and they were but little pleaed at the gain of the Battel, ince their hopes were furtrated.

Acomat wondred that Muelman, who had o many reaons to fear the Sultan's wrath, hould be o rah as to enter his Camp, and carry away Ariania, being not acquainted with all the particulars of his Life, he could give no comfort to the King of Albania.

In the mean time this Prince could ee the Turks had departed, that his Army was not much weakned, and that Croyae had nothing to fear; being thus free to act as he pleaed, he could not reolve himelf to tarry, till he had heard ome News concerning Ariania, and reolved to venture any thing to find her out. My Lord, ays he to Aranit, our common interet requires mine abence; as things tand now, there is no danger Amurat hould attempt any thing, but we ought to fear all things from the treacherous Muelman. We mut deliver Ariania from his Tyranny,
and I am weary of my life, when I think he is in his power. Aranit was far from oppoing this reolution, and Scanderberg prepared himelf to depart with the fortunate Thopia, who would never forake him. ranus followed them alo, and Acomat, who could not with Honour follow his Mater's Enemies, tarried with Aranit as a Prioner of War.

The King of Alhania would not take many Souldiers along with him, for fear of being known, his Equipage was not very great; but he found himelf in an exceeding trouble, concerning the way he ought to take; he was enible that Muelman had fled from Amurat, and that it was to no purpoe to eek him among the defeated Army; it was not likely neither, that this Raviher hould retire into the Emperour's Territories, or tarry in Albania. In this uncertainty he wholly truted himelf to Chance: not certain of the ucces of his Enterprize, and going he knew not where, he found in everal places many Companies of the Turks cattered, and returning to Amurat. He was three days without taking any ret, and all his inquiries being to no purpoe, he began to depair.

But he was not the only man that ought Ariania. Prince Mahomet eeing her out of his Father's hands, deired to get her for himelf, and look'd upon Muelman as upon a light obtacle, could he but meet with him. Amurat, tho' orely afflicted at his loes, ent everal Parties after him; but the young Sultan, led by his own heart's interet, took that licence followed only by twenty men.

At firt he was not more fortunate than Scanderberg, and travelled over a pacious Country to no purpoe; at lat being arrived in a avage place, which properly may be called a Wildernes, he heard ome noie over his head, and aw Muelman retrenched in a teep Rock hurrying Ariania with violence, and triving to get her, notwithtanding all her reitance, into a Den, where the Sun had never hone.

Mahomet had an Ottoman Soul (that is, haughty and cruel) as the ret of his Life witneed. The injury done to a fair Princes, whom he loved dearly, inpired him with the utmot Fury, and crying very loud, he would fain have gone to Muelman, but he aw every where inacceible Precipices. Ariania
and Muelman hearing that noie, look'd upon him. The Princes hated all the Turks, but he had a leer averion againt Mahomet than againt the Botangi-Bachi; the Prince who aw her deolate, and oppreed with grief, made many attempts, which did not affright Muelman; but Heaven, who had deigned that day for the punihment of the greatet Rogue in the World, brought Scanderberg and his Men in the place where the Prince Mahomet was, it vexed them to ee one another there, but the King of Albania oon perceived Ariania. Who could expres his commotion at this ight? or Muelman's rage? The Precipices that were round him, eem'd to ecure his Cruelty; but uch as they were, he did not think they were inacceible for the paionate Scanderberg. Jut Heavens, cry'd he, favour my Paion, and ince you grant me to ee Ariania, grant me alo that I may deliver her from that cruel Tyrant. Then he cat his eyes all round about, and eeing a byway difficult, but les dangerous than the ret, followed it hatily. Thopia, ranus, and the ret followed his teps, and Mahomet, who would not be an
ueles Spectator, went after them, tho it was a long circuit, and tho' Muelman affrighted, threatned to carry away Ariania, the couragious Princes hindered his deign. Scanderberg aw many of his Men fall, and bruie themelves upon the Rocks; but this did not abate his Courage, and at lat he found a way eaier and broader, which led him to Arianisa.

But alas! thoe were not all the obtacles he was to met with, and Muelman's Fury was more to be feared than thoe Precipices he had overcome already. That barbarous man, tho' he had a far greater number of men, than thoe that had followed the two Princes, yet could not trut on his own trength: a hellih rage poes'd his Soul, and eeing he was undone, he reolved to undo all. With this reolution, he eized Arianisa's arm, and drawing a Cymeter, Scanderberg, aid he to her, with his cared looks, hall never ee thee alive, or enjoy thoe favours thou deignet for him. Thou cannot affright me, in threatning me with death, replied Arianisa, with a erene countenance, but tremble for thine own. I look upon it as certain, replied
the Turk, but Scanderberg's hand hall never acrifice me.

The King of Albania was till drawing nearer, and could already hear them. Muelman perceiving him, bad him top if he deired Ariania's life. The Prince, who aw his Cymeter, and who was well enough acquainted with the Turks temper, to expect all orts of cruelties from them, was trangely urpried, and durt go no farther. Ariania eeing him top, and fearing let too much love hould make him eaily leave her, exhorted him to advance. Come, my Lord, cryed he to him, Muelman is too faint hearted to attempt any thing upon my life, but uppoe he was not, I would ooner die than ubmit to him. Mahomet, who had alo drawn near, and who was not o much concerned for the los of her life, tho' he was mightily in love, would have advanced farther; but Scanderberg bad him imperiouly not to advance rahly, let he hould conider him as Ariania's Murderer. The Prince advanced no more, and Muelman eeing the well grounded fear of his Rivals grew the more inolent. King of Albania, aid he, if thou lovet Ariania's life, thou mut allow
me to retire freely with her, ince I wear to thee by all that may render an Oath inviolable, that I hall not pare her, if thou goet a tep farther. O barbarous! cry'd the Prince, is this your way of loving and deerving her? How cunningly thou knowet how to make ue of my Love and thy Cowardie! Depart Monter, go far from hence, ince Ariania's afety requires it; but at leat repect her Virtue and Rank. Can you forake me o, cryed out Aranit's fair Daughter, and do you think, Scanderberg, that I am o much in love with my life as to chue to live with this Monter? How blameworthy is your faint-heartednes! Mut my own example encourage you? If you do not come to me, I will go meet either Death or you; then he attempted to get looe out of Muelman's hands, but her trength was not ufficient: Muelman foreaw then his certain ruine: Love, aid he, without any more ado, guide mine Arm: Then he lifted it up to tab Arania in the breat; and he had certainly done it, if the affectionate Thopia, whoe mind was more edate than Scanderberg's, foreeeing the effects of Muelman's rage,
had not taken ecretly a by way, and got in that critical minute o near him that he truck him, and ent both his Arm and Dagger to Ariania's Feet; another blow divided Muelman's Face in two, o that he gave up his unclean Soul with his cruel Blood.

Thoe that were there preent were o amazed at this wonderful Action that they took Thopia for a Man ent down from Heaven: But Scanderberg, whoe terrour was converted into a udden joy, ran to embrace Ariania's Deliverer before he went to her elf. 'Tis impoible for us to relate all the obliging things they told one another. Scanderberg, to hew his great paion, protrated himelf at Ariania's Feet, and uttered the mot paionate expreions that his heart could invent. She embraced him obligingly, at which favour Mahomet was orely vexed. Thopia received from Ariania uch Praies and Elogiums as his Action well deerved; and Scanderberg hewed him all the imaginable demontrations of joy and friendhip. The Turks who had follow'd Muelman fled away, but they were not purued. Mahomet did igh, having no hope left him; and eeing
there was now no likelihood to pa ••
Ariania from Scanderberg: Cru •• Fortune, cryed he, why mut I be the witnes of their Felicity? Mut I forake for ever a Beauty whom I have o long ador'd? Having made this orrowful reflection, he came near Scanderberg with as much freedom as he might have done at Andrianople. Tho' we are both Enemies and Rivals, aid he to him, I fear nothing from thee which might be unworthy of a Prince whom all the World admires, and without any bae ubmiion I mut tell thee, I eteem thee, tho' without love. Compare my condition to think own, and grant that I am an unfortunate Man, ince neither in my Father's Dominions, nor in this place. I have any hopes left me. Could a reaonably expect to fight for her with ucces, and gain her favour, the Ottoman Blood which runs in my veine hould never be allarmed at thy valour. I ee you mut remain Conquerour, and ince thou hat triumphed over Amurat, you can never be vanquihed, and I cannot but be unfortunate for ever.

Thee words which could not proceed but from a noble heart, made a
deep impreion upon Scanderberg; he had always been enible of Mahomet's excellent Virtues, which anwered well his Illutrious Birth; and eeing that he could not in reaon upbraid him of his Pride; My Lord, aid he to him, I hall never hate you, tho' you can never love me; and I would willingly part with any thing beides Ariania for your atisfaction. Time, interrupted Mahomet, will without doubt afford us ome occaions to ee one another again. In the mean time, enjoy your Ariania, whom I cannot take away from you. Having poke thee words, away he rode, and was oon out of ight with his Men.

Scanderberg reolved to tarry no longer in a place where Ariania had been o adly allarmed, and which was like to have proved fatal to her. They told one another a thouand obliging things; and they choe the fairet Hore for the beautiful Princes, who rode towards Croya, with her illutrious Lover, leaving Muelman's Corps to be devoured by wild Beats, wherewith thoe Dearts were full.

Tho' Ariania was not ued to any hard exercie, yet he rode a long way
within a hort time; and he cou •• hardly be perwaded to take any <> at night; the trong deire he <> to ee Aranit, Amia, and her other dear Relations, made her long to arrive at Croya. During that Journey which lated two days and a night, Scanderberg had now the opportunity •• knowing his own good fortune, and Ariania's tender love. Thopia was as well pleaed as he; and never did •• greater tranquillity ucceed trouble which were thought endles.

In fine, Scanderberg brought into Croya without meeting with any oppoition, his fair Princes: All the People of the City went in great crowds to ee her, and to congratulate him upon his return. Aranit then the mot fortunate of Fathers, told Scanderberg, That ince he had deerved o well his Daughter he belonged by right to him: Amia and Ariania kied and embraced one another for a long while; and Thopia, who had been o glorious an Intrument in procuring Scanderberg's Happines, receiv'd from Amia uch protetations of Love as he deerved.

Croya, where Sorrow had reigned during the War, and Scanderberg's Grief,
then quite alter'd, Pleaures and Sports had now their time, and all poible endeavours were made to divert Ariania, who had led before uch a orrowful life. Among all thee pleaing Diverions, Scanderberg neglected nothing concerning his important Affairs; and whilt Amurat was hearing what had pas'd, and was taking new reolutions, both againt the Life and Fortune of the King of Albania, this Prince who now enjoy'd his dear Ariania, kept his Army in a capacity of reiting all the Ottoman Forces.

He knew not what had pas'd at Andrinople ince his departure thence: Ariania who had een Acomat, and bewailed the Death of the Loyal Aradin, was willing to atisfy Scanderberg's Curioity; one Evening being with Amia and Thopia, who had heard her former Adventures, he thus related the lat to the King of Albania.

div.head: The Hitory of ARIANISSA.
div.p:
AS I had paionately wihed for your departure from Andrinople, o was I overjoy'd at the News of it, ince you ought not to expect there any favour;
and tho' I could not abolutely flatter my elf with the Idea of a future Liberty, yet I had ome glimmering hope till left me. Aradin and I congratulated one another upon this occaion; but the fearful Sultan fell into an exceeding Rage, when he heard you had been proclaimed King by the Albanians.

As his wrath increaed, o did his troubleome and imperious Sollicitations: He did not quetion, but I had ome ecret Intelligence with you; and he upected Aradin of having favour'd our Deigns; he threatned him with Death, and me with the utmot Severity, and o cat me often into dreadful Fears.

p.U: eeing he had lot you for ever, endeavoured to regain the Sultan's Love; I did what I could to facilitate that Conquet unto her, yet he hated me as a dangerous Rival, who deprived her of the Sultan's Affection, and who likely had hindred you from loving her: She conjectured from the words which you heard me ing, and which truly proceeded from my heart, that ince the day you fought the Tartar, I had not look't upon you with indifference.

div.p: Prince Mahomet, who was no longer oberved by you, and who feared only his Father's Jealouie, reolved to venture any thing to ee me; and the cunning Muelman got alo into the Seraglio, after the way I hall relate to you.

Amurat thought, that having no hope left of your return, I hould never be able to reit him; but eeing all his moderation was to no purpoe, after he had ighed, he began to threaten, and hew'd me all that cruel Pride natural to the Ottoman Blood. You try my patience too far, cruel and ungrateful Ariania, aid he one day to me, and you do not regard at all my kindnes for you. Do you think I pare you by reaon of my own weaknes? No ure, but my Heart protects you againt my Reaon; you ought therefore to own your elf obliged to me; otherwie I wear by all the Powers above, that I hall make ue of all mine Authority, if your unkindnes forces me to it.

This Dicoure had been proceeded by o many of the like nature, that I did not look upon it as a new thing, but Amurat's countenance was quite changed. Thou knowet well, that I never
abued thy Highnes, reply'd I, and that I never promied thee any thing; I am enible both of thy Power and Dignity: But, my Lord, thou oughtet to know, That thou cant not require from me, but the repect due to thy Rank; I am no peron of a mean Birth, and the Chains I am loaded with cannot depres my Courage; thoe Countries which are ubject to thy Power, afford thee Beauty's enough, whoe only deire is to pleae thee; thy Religion allows them that liberty, and their Inclinations are agreeable with the condition; as for me, Fortune only had made me thy Slave; I am not thy Subject, if thou art jut, and there are Laws above thine, which forbid me to favour a Mahometan. If Scanderberg did it upon the Ottoman Throne, reply'd the angry Sultan, you would not be likely o nice; and all your Reaons about Independance and Contancy, would not prove o trong as you pretend them. Well, Ariania, aid he proudly, perit in your reolution; but expect no longer from me any moderation, ince I will have no more regard to your Sex, your Religion, or your Birth.
Being in uch a humour, he left me; Selimana exaperated him by her Reproaches, and both the Seraglio's were witnees of his violent Rage.

Since the Converation I had had with the Sultanes in the Garden, and which you heard: Our Friendhip had not been great, becaue Amurat's love changed oon after, and for reaon of the new rank which he forced me to take; he judged by what had happen'd in the Garden, where he had deir'd me to walk with her, when the Emperour met us, that you were no indifferent Peron to me; he had look'd upon the Sultanes love, as upon a thing which authorized in ome manner her freedom with me, and her in contancy: But when he knew that you lov'd me, and that I had ome gratitude for you, he fell in a Rage againt me, and call'd me perfidious and treacherous, becaue he had truted me with the Secret of her own Heart.

The Emperour who went by, interrupted us; he was that day in a rage that cannot be expreed, having heard of the new progres of your Valour; he upbraided me for it, without conidering the pleaure he gave me, by telling me of thee News.

But, my Lord, 'tis time to acquaint you with a more remarkable paage: I was one night upon a little Terras, which rendred mine Apartment very pleaant; the Emperour kept his Bed by reaon of a violent Feaver, which proceeded from his Anger. I was thinking upon your Advantages, and I had pent part of the night in that pleaing Occupation, had I not been interrupted. I heard at the foot of the Terras, a Voice, which I knew preently to be Amaldan's, becaue there
was none weeter than his in the Seraglio, and by reaon we had ung often together to divert Selimana, he ung but thee four Veres, likely of his own making.

q.l: Awake, prepare for gentle Love's Alarm:
No, prying Argus now can do you harm.
And whilt all things are here by leep poet,
May you in weet Delights of Love be blet.

div.p: I hearkned to Amaldan; thinking he had no deign; but turning my head at a little noie, I aw a Slave, whom I took to be one of thoe Women that waited upon me; but it proved the bold Muelman in that Diguie.

I cannot expres my amazement and my wrath; this way going to break out againt the Botangi Bachi, when another Woman (as I thought) drew near me, as rah as the firt, and in the ame Diguie; this was Prince Mahomet.

Had I followed my firt paion, I had ruined them both, and drawn likely upon my elf the upition of favouring
one or the other; they were as much amazed as I at the Conformity of their Adventures. After I had look'd upon them a long while, to be the better aured, that I was not mitaken; at lat I told them, that they hazarded more than I, and that their Enterprizes which rendred them o guilty towards the Emperour, could not prove pernicious to me. There is no need, aid I, I hould intruct you about the Laws, which you know well enough, and which you cannot violate, without Crime or Danger. But, my Lord, aid I, turning my elf towards Mahomet, I mut needs tell you, that tho' my civility may hide your Actions from the Sultan, yet you ought to make a good ue of it: And as for thee, O Muelman, the perfidious Subject of an Emperour, who had honoured thee with the firt Diguities of his Houe, if thou ecapet free; thank my Indulgence and Mahomet.
The Botangi Bachi felt a ecret Rage at thee words; he believed that your abence had changed mine Inclinations, and that I was in love with the young Sultan.

I have interrupted your Deigns, reply'd he, with a boldnes like himelf: You wih Mahomet hould come again; but I am not o little concerned in Amurat's Interet, as to hide from him what has pas'd. You Rogue, interrupted the Prince, do not offend Ariania, and acknowledge your fault as I do mine. Since our paionate Love hath brought us hither, againt all common prudence, let us confes our elves guilty: Tho' you ought to quetion me about what I do, yet tho' I am your Prince, I'll give you what atisfaction you can deire from me: Come therefore to another place. Thee words did but confirm him in the Opinion he had, that I loved Mahomet; they were both forced to retire; and after I had een them go out, I went into my Chamber, reolved to tarry there for fear of the like Surprial, eeing that all the Eunuchs in the Seraglio were debauched in their Duty. Amaldan, who deign'd nothing ele by favouring the Botangi Bachi, than to make ue of his Liberality, cared little whether he was pleaed or no; thoe that erved Mahomet, were not more zealous for him.

Some of my waiting Women had their Share in this Intreague, but for fear of communicating thee things to thoe that were innocent, I thought it fitter to be ilent; I got all the Pages to my Appartment cloely hut up. Aradin did awage my dipleaure, by telling me he had received News from you, and that nothing being able to reit you, you would oon be Mater of Croya.
Your happines made me look les melancholly than I was ued to be, Amurat, who was ick but a little while, oon perceived it, and upbraided me for my edate mind, as if it had been a great Crime.

In fine, My Lord, we heard at Adrianople your arrival to Croya, and I cannot expres to you, what was Amurat's rage, when he heard of the defeat of his Baha's; he reolved to go in peron to fight you. But he was not willing to leave me behind him. I was not afflicted at this news, reckoning it a happines to come near the place, where you and my Father were, Selimana mad at this Reolution, deigned to have killed me, and to make her elf certain that way, that I hould never belong to you, or to the Sultan.

I have told you already that we had no great correpondance. She knew what preparations were made for my departure, and eeing he had quite lot the Emperours love, he reolved to punih me for it; by her liberality he endeavoured to induce ome Eunuchs to poion me, ome were peridious enough to attempt againt my Life, but all to no purpoe, tho' I ued but a little circumpection. Thee low enterpries, did not agree with the violence of her hatred; therefore one night, being mad at Amurat's Scorn, he entered into my Chamber, with a dagger in her hand, which he had ued without any mercy, had not my good Fate brought there Aradin, who, full of Zeal and Terror, threw himelf upon her, and hindred her deign. The proud Sultanes turned her head, and perceived her own weaknes, he told us all that a violent hatred can inpire. She cured the Emperour; reviled me baely, proteted againt me, named you many times, and at lat tabbing her elf with two trokes, he fell dead at my feet.

I ran away at this cruel ight. The Emperour coming in was little concerned for her Death, tho' he had loved
her paionately, becaue he could no longer abide her apbraiding humour.

At lat, my Lord, we departed from the Seraglio at Andrinople; I was put in a covered Cart with two old Women, it was impoible for any man to ee me, and no body was ever oberved with greater care, notwithtanding all this, the rah Muelman endeavoured to teal me away; he was dicovered the firt time, and forced to fly from the preence of the angry Sultan, who was reolved to have punihed him; he upected Mahomet alo, and that poor Prince was like to undergo the Fate, which hath ruined o many of his Predeceors.

We arrived in ight of Croya, with the Ottoman Army. I felt ome tender motions, when I aw thee Towers, and Amurat redoubled then his Efforts to often my heart but never found me Kinder, than I had been at Andrinople. Vexed at this, he would always threaten me with your or Arianit's death. I was often alarmed at his: But the trut I had in the Valour of you both, diipated my Terrors, and kept up my Courage.

One day after he had extraordinarily
tormented me, he reolved to acrifice me to that rage my unkindnes had caued in him, he thought he hould forget me, when he hould ee me no more; and being loath to ue any other Executioner, than his loyal Orcan, a favourite, worthy uch a Mater, he wrote the Note to him, which you found upon Aradin, and truted it to an Eunuch. Aradin, who knew the exceeding and violent wrath of Sultan, oberved all his Actions, and meeting the Eunuch, who carried his orders to Orcan; he likely brought him out of the Camp, and fought him, having no other way to get his Note of him; I do not quetion but he went towards Croya, to acquaint you with my mierable condition, but he was aainated in the way by Muelman, who had never loved him, according to what he told me, after he had tolen me away, that he had already acrificed that paion to himelf.
I expected nothing good from Amurat's Anger, and eeing Aradin no longer, I thought he had been arreted by his Orders, as being too much affected for your Service and mine.

As Paions are not always equally
violent he had no ooner ordered my death, but he thought with himelf, how cruel this was like to prove to him; he ent for the Eunuch, but he was no longer to be found.

Amurat at lat aw Orcan, who had not received his orders, and who had never approved it. Conidering what advantage it would be to them to keep me alive, in a Country where the chance of War might not favour them always. Amurat, who had harkened to his own reaons, more than to thoe of Orcan, gave me leave to live, but wore he hould have no longer any repect for me.

You know, my Lord, all the ret that had pat, my Father's captivity, your own Victories, and Muelman's tealing me away; he broke open the Tent where I was carefully kept, killed many men, and carryed me away without any reitance, auring me, that to make amends for what he had done, his only deire was to deliver me into your hands; I could not trut him, but that dicoure flattered my hopes; that Traytor brought me away with all the immaginable wiftnes, whilt all the Camp was full of confuion, and I lot
oon after the ight of the Walls of Croya, and that of Amurat's Tents.

You may judge, my Lord, of my grief, to fall from Amurat's hands, into that Traytor's, whom no conideration had been able to divert from uch a dangerous attempt. I weeped, but all to no purpoe, my Prayers were but in vain, he made me wander a long while, without letting me enjoy any ret, and hurried me in that place, whether Heaven moved by my tears brought you in uch a Critical Minute.

The Princes made an end of her Dicoure, Scanderberg hew'd how much moved he was at her everal ufferings; in the mean time, Aranit came to acquaint the King, that the Turks fortify'd themelves, and did intend to attack them within few days; but Scanderberg was no les formidable in his joy than in his orrow, and was not much frighted at Amurat's deigns.

All the moments he pent with the Charming Ariania, were attended with happines, and joy. Thopia alo, who feared no longer any Rival, nor the King's oppoition againt his Love, enjoy'd a perfect Tranquility, which Amia's Protetations aured him of.

Amurat grievouly vexed to know his Enemy's perfect happines, offered him the Battle again, and made a new attempt to oppres him. Ariania, who was well acquainted with Fortune's incontancy, was afflicted at it; but the invincible Scanderberg auring her o confidently of the Victory, render'd her les concerned at his departure.

And really he triumphed again, but after uch a glorious and advantagious a manner, that the Sultan being vanquih'd, and weakned, dyed ome days after for hame and dipair, after his lat defeat; Mahomet, who was not then in a capacity to make War any longer, eeing the Ottoman Army exhauted, left Ariania, and Albania in the Victorious Scanderberg's hands, and went to Andrinople to be proclaim'd Emperor there. Acomat being at liberty to do what he pleaed, followed him and parted from Scanderberg, after he had promied him an everlating Friendhip, which he religiouly oberved, being neuter in all the Wars, between Mahomet, and the King of Albania.

Scanderberg, at the highet degree of his glory, feared by his Enemies, adored
by all his Subjects, and dearly beloved by the fairet Princes in the World, married her publickly in Croya, with all poible demontrations of joy; the ame day was choen for Thopia's marriage with Amia. Aranit full of Satisfaction and Glory, took upon himelf the management of State Affairs, to give more time to Scanderberg, to enjoy Loves delights. All thoe that had been Loyal to Catriot's Family were fully rewarded, chiefly ranus. Never a King lived with more content, or performed uch famous Exploits as Scanderberg did. But 'tis enough for us to have tyed him here for ever with his Charming Ariania. The great Atchievements of his Reign, are o commonly known, that it would be to no purpoe to relate them here.
